{{Infobox person | name = Eli Broad | image = Eli Broad in 2011.jpg<!-- just the name, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = Broad in 2011 at the [[University of California, San Francisco]]. | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1933|06|06}} | birth_place = [[Bronx]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | residence = [[Los Angeles]], California, U.S. | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|Month DD, YYYY|Month DD, YYYY}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = American | other_names = | known_for = | alma_mater = [[Michigan State University]] | occupation = Founder, The Broad Foundations; Co-founder, [[KB Home]]; Founder, SunAmerica | spouse = Edythe Lawson | children = 2 | networth = {{steady}} US$7.4 [[1,000,000,000 (number)|billion]] (February 2015)<ref name="ForbesList">{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/eli-broad/|title=The World's Billionaires - Eli Broad|accessdate=2015-10-27|publisher=[[Forbes]]|website=Forbes}}</ref> }}
'''Eli Broad''' ({{IPAc-en|b|r|oʊ|d}}; born June 6, 1933) is an [[Americans|American]] [[entrepreneur]] and [[philanthropist]]. He is the only person to build two [[Fortune 500]] companies<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.givesmart.org/Stories/Donors/Eli-Broad|title=Eli Broad's Pursuit of "Unreasonable" Philanthropy|work=givesmart.org}}</ref> in different industries ([[KB Home]] and [[SunAmerica]]). As of October 2015, [[Forbes]] ranked Broad the 65th wealthiest person in the world, with an estimated net worth of $7.4 billion.<ref name="ForbesList"/>
==Early life and education== Broad was born in 1933 in the [[Bronx]], [[New York (state)|New York]], the only child of [[Lithuanian Jews|Lithuanian Jewish]] immigrant parents who met in New York.<ref name=Unreasonable>{{cite book |last1=Broad |first1=Eli |date=2012-05-08 |title=The Art of Being Unreasonable |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LJZqGV1SsasC&lpg=PP1&dq=the%20art%20of%20being%20unreasonable&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q=the%20art%20of%20being%20unreasonable&f=false |publisher=wiley |isbn=978-1118173213}}</ref>{{Page needed|date=October 2015}}<ref name=LAMAG>[https://books.google.com/books?id=u10EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA145&lpg=PA145&dq=broad#v=onepage&q=broad&f=false Los Angeles Magazine: "A Little Thing Called Power - He has more pull than the mayor, more art than the Getty, and more money than God. Does El Broad own LA?" by Ed Leibowitz] June 2003</ref> His father worked as a house painter, and his mother worked as a dressmaker.<ref name=Unreasonable />{{Page needed|date=October 2015}} His family moved to [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] when he was six years old.<ref name=Unreasonable /><ref name=LAMAG /> In Detroit, his father was a [[union organizer]], and owned [[five-and-dime stores]].<ref name=BruckNYer2010>Bruck, Connie, "The Art of the Billionaire", ''The New Yorker'', December 10, 2010</ref> Broad attended [[Detroit Public Schools]] and graduated from [[Central High School (Detroit, Michigan)|Detroit Central High School]] in 1951.<ref name=Unreasonable />{{Page needed|date=October 2015}}<ref name=LAMAG />
Broad attended [[Michigan State University]], majoring in accounting with a minor in economics and graduating ''[[cum laude]]'' in 1954. Among the jobs Broad held in college were selling women's shoes, selling [[garbage disposal]]s door-to-door, and working as a [[drill press]] operator at [[Packard|Packard Motor]], where he was a member of [[United Auto Workers]].<ref name="Unreasonable"/>{{Page needed|date=October 2015}} The same year, 21-year-old Broad married 18-year-old Edythe "Edye" Lawson.<ref name=Unreasonable />{{Page needed|date=October 2015}}
Broad became the youngest Michigan resident to attain the credentials of [[Certified Public Accountant]] (CPA), a record he held until 2010. Broad worked as an accountant for two years and taught night classes at the [[Detroit Institute of Technology]] as an assistant professor of accounting in 1956.<ref name="Unreasonable" />{{Page needed|date=October 2015}} Wanting to work on his own, he founded his own accounting firm and was offered office space by the husband of his wife's cousin, [[Donald Bruce Kaufman]], in return for doing the books for Kaufman's small homebuilding and subcontracting business.<ref name=LAMAG />
==Career== ===Kaufman & Broad=== Doing the accounting for Kaufman's small business led Broad to decide to enter homebuilding himself. In 1956, Broad and Kaufman decided to partner and build homes together.<ref name=LAMAG /> Borrowing $12,500 from his wife's parents, Broad put up half the capital in their first venture together, building two model homes in the Northeast Detroit suburbs<ref name=LAMAG /> where a new generation of first-time home buyers were flocking. By streamlining the construction process and eliminating basements, offering a carport instead, they could price the houses so the monthly mortgage would be less than the rent for a two-bedroom apartment. Kaufman and Broad christened this model the "Award Winner" and priced it at $13,700.<ref name=LAMAG /><ref name=BruckNYer2010 /> After one weekend, seventeen were sold and within two years, Kaufman and Broad had built 600 homes in the Detroit suburbs.<ref name=LAMAG /> In 1960, fearing that the Detroit economy was too dependent on the automotive business, they moved to Phoenix, Arizona.<ref name=LAMAG /> In 1961, Kaufman and Broad Home Corporation (now [[KB Home]]) [[initial public offering|went public]] on the [[American Stock Exchange]].<ref name=ReutersKBH>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/overview?symbol=KBH | work=Reuters | title=KB Home (KBH)}}</ref> In 1963, Broad moved the company to [[Los Angeles]]. Soon after, Kaufman retired and he and his wife [[Glorya Kaufman]] went on to become noted philanthropists.<ref name=LAMAG /> By 1969, KB Home was the first homebuilder listed on the [[New York Stock Exchange]].<ref name=ReutersKBH /> In 1974, Broad stepped down as CEO.<ref name=LAMAG />
===SunAmerica=== {{Main|SunAmerica}} In 1971, Broad acquired Sun Life Insurance Company of America, a family-owned insurance company founded in [[Baltimore]] in 1890, for $52 million.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://broadfoundation.org/about-us/|title=About Us {{!}} The Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation|work=The Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation|access-date=2017-08-08|language=en-US}}</ref> Broad transformed Sun Life into the retirement savings powerhouse [[SunAmerica]]. In 1999, he sold SunAmerica to the [[American International Group]] (AIG) for $18 billion.<ref>https://www.sunamerica.com/TridionData.do?Page_ID=67997</ref> Broad continued as CEO of SunAmerica until 1999, when he left to focus on [[philanthropy]] full-time.
===Writing=== In 2012, Broad's first book, ''The Art of Being Unreasonable: Lessons in Unconventional Thinking'',<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-eli-broad-book-20120504,0,4402401.story|title=Eli Broad offers life lessons in|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|first1=Mike|last1=Boehm|date=2014-05-04|accessdate=2015-10-27}}</ref> was published by [[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley and Sons]] and debuted as a ''[[The New York Times Best Seller list|New York Times]]'', ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[USA Today]]'', and ''[[Washington Post]]'' bestseller.<ref>{{cite web|title=Eli and Edythe Broad|url=http://www.thebroad.org/about/eli-and-edythe-broad|publisher=The Broad|accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Eli L. BROAD|url=http://www.wealthx.com/billionaires/eli-l-broad/|publisher=Wealth|accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref>
==Philanthropy and civic engagement== [[Image:Caltrans District 7 HQ.jpg|thumb|right|220px|The Eli and Edythe Broad Plaza in front of the [[Caltrans District 7 Headquarters]]]] Eli and Edythe Broad created '''The Broad Foundations'''<ref>[http://www.broadfoundation.org/about_broads.html Eli and Edythe Broad.] The Broad Foundations. Retrieved July 18, 2013.</ref> to advance entrepreneurship for the public good in education, science and the arts. The Broad Foundations, which include '''The Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation''' and '''The Broad Art Foundation''', have assets of $3 billion.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://broadfoundation.org/gerun-riley-named-president-eli-edythe-broad-foundation/|title=Gerun Riley Named President of The Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation {{!}} The Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation|date=2016-08-22|work=The Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation|access-date=2017-08-08|language=en-US}}</ref>
In 2010, the Broads announced their participation in "[[The Giving Pledge]]," a commitment for wealthy individuals to give at least half of their wealth to charity.<ref>{{cite news|last=Campbell |first=Dakin |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-06-17/broad-commits-75-of-wealth-to-charity-takes-buffett-up-on-giving-pledge.html |title=Broad, Bloomberg Back Buffett Call for Billionaire Donations |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2010-06-17 |accessdate=2011-04-25}}</ref> The Broads personally committed to giving 75% of their wealth away.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://philanthropy.com/article/A-Plea-for-Greater-Giving/66195/|title=A Plea for Greater Giving|work=The Chronicle of Philanthropy}}</ref>
In 2017, Broad announced his retirement from The Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation, passing responsibility to its president, Gerun Riley. Broad said he would remain as a trustee of the foundation, and continue to serve on the Board of The Broad museum. Broad said he was in good health and felt like it was time to "step back".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/business/billionaire-la-philanthropist-eli-broad-retires-at-84/ |title=Billionaire LA philanthropist Eli Broad retires at 84 |publisher=AP |date=13 October 2017 |accessdate=14 October 2017}}</ref>
===Education=== The stated mission of the Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation's education work is to ensure that every student in an urban public school has the opportunity to succeed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://broadeducation.org/about/overview.html|title=Mission and Overview|work=broadeducation.org|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130806205741/http://www.broadeducation.org/about/overview.html|archivedate=2013-08-06|df=}}</ref> The foundation has made $589 million in grants since it launched in 1999.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://broadfoundation.org/education/|title=Education {{!}} The Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation|work=The Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation|access-date=2017-08-08|language=en-US}}</ref>
====The Broad Prize==== From 2002 to 2014, The Broad Foundation awarded an annual $1 million [[Broad Prize for Urban Education]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadprize.org|title=Home Page - The Broad Prize for Urban Education|work=broadprize.org}}</ref> The Broad Prize recognized the large urban school districts in America that have made the greatest improvement in student achievement while narrowing achievement gaps among low-income students and students of color. The Broad Prize has awarded $16 million in college scholarships to high school seniors since 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadprize.org/news/668.html|title=Press Releases|work=broadprize.org}}</ref> In 2012, the foundation launched the Broad Prize for Public Charter Schools, which awards $250,000 to the top charter management organization in the country. In 2015, the foundation announced that it was suspending the Broad Prize for Urban Education.
====The Broad Center==== The Broad Center<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcenter.org|title=The Broad Center|work=broadcenter.org}}</ref> in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], [[California]], is a [[nonprofit organization]] that seeks to prepare strong leaders of public school systems through The Broad Superintendents Academy<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcenter.org/academy|title=Academy - The Broad Center: Academy|work=broadcenter.org|access-date=2013-08-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130625114153/http://www.broadcenter.org/academy/|archive-date=2013-06-25|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> (unaccredited) and The Broad Residency in Urban Education (accredited).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcenter.org/residency|title=Residency - The Broad Center: Residency|work=broadcenter.org|access-date=2013-08-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130818025045/http://www.broadcenter.org/residency/|archive-date=2013-08-18|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> It is wholly funded by the Broad Foundation.
===Arts=== Broad has been an influential figure in the art world since 1973 and has had a particular focus on the cultural life of [[Los Angeles]].
[[Image:Broad Art Center, by Meier.jpg|thumb|Broad Art Center, by Meier at the [[UCLA School of the Arts and Architecture]]]] Broad was the founding chairman of the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles]] in 1979 and chaired the board until 1984. He recruited the founding director of the museum<ref>Peter Aspden, [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/4e3eb722-ca62-11de-a3a3-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1CiXYf0XM Putting LA at the heart of world culture] Financial Times, November 6, 2009. Accessed February 1, 2011.</ref> and negotiated the acquisition of the [[Giuseppe Panza|Panza Collection]] for the museum.
In 2008, The Broad Foundation gave a $30 million challenge grant to rebuild the museum’s endowment and to provide exhibition support. The Foundation's donation was contingent on the museum remaining independent and not merging with [[LACMA|Los Angeles County Museum of Art]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/23/arts/design/23moca.html | work=The New York Times | first=Edward | last=Wyatt | title=Billionaire Offers Arts Bailout in Los Angeles | date=November 23, 2008}}</ref>
Broad is a life trustee of the [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]] (LACMA). In 2003, The Broad Foundation gave $60 million to the museum as part of its renovation campaign to create the Broad Contemporary Art Museum and for an art acquisition fund.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Boehm |first=Mike |title=BP gives $25 million to LACMA: The BP donation will go toward a solar entrance that the British oil firm hopes will invoke energy innovation. |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=March 6, 2007 |url=http://www.calendarlive.com/printedition/calendar/cl-et-lacma6mar06,0,1254648.story?coll=cl-calendar |format=– <sup>[https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=author%3ABoehm+intitle%3ABP+gives+%2425+million+to+LACMA%3A+The+BP+donation+will+go+toward+a+solar+entrance+that+the+British+oil+firm+hopes+will+invoke+energy+innovation.&as_publication=&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]</sup> |postscript=<!--None--> }}{{dead link|date=February 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
The Broads provided the lead gift of $6 million to the [[Los Angeles Opera]] to bring [[Richard Wagner]]'s [[List of literary cycles|opera cycle]] ''[[Der Ring des Nibelungen]]'' to Los Angeles for the 2009–10 season.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/08/arts/design/08broad.html | work=The New York Times | first=Jennifer | last=Steinhauer | title=Iron Checkbook Shapes Cultural Los Angeles | date=February 8, 2010}}</ref> In June 2013, the Broads gave $7 million to continue funding the Eli and Edythe Broad general director at L.A. Opera, currently occupied by [[Plácido Domingo]].
The Broads contributed $10 million in 2008 for a programming [[Financial endowment|endowment]] for a state-of-the-art music and [[performing arts center]] at [[Santa Monica College]], The Eli and Edythe Broad Stage, and an adjacent [[Black box theater|black box performance space]], The Edye.
In total, the Broads have given roughly $1 billion to Los Angeles art institutions. Broad now calls Los Angeles a "cultural capital of the world".<ref>{{cite news|last=Wolfe|first=Alexandra|title=Eli Broad's Entrepreneurial Approach to Philanthropy|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324549004579067223556724780|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=September 16, 2013}}</ref>
====The Broad==== {{Main|The Broad}} [[File:Broad Museum LA.JPG|thumb|right|The Broad museum under construction, 2015]] In August 2010, Eli Broad announced formally that he would build a contemporary art museum in Downtown Los Angeles.<ref>David Ng and Jori Finkel (August 24, 2010), [http://articles.latimes.com/2010/aug/24/entertainment/la-et--broad-museum-20100823 Eli Broad says Grand Avenue will be site of new contemporary art museum] ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''.</ref> Diller Scofidio + Renfro were chosen through an architectural competition to design the approximately 120,000-square-foot museum, which includes exhibition space, offices and a parking garage.<ref>David Ng and Jori Finkel (August 23, 2010), [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2010/08/its-official-eli-broad-will-build-his-art-museum-downtown-diller-scofidio-renfro-will-design.html It's official: Eli Broad will build his art museum downtown; Diller Scofidio + Renfro will design] ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''.</ref>
In February 2015, a public preview of a special installation attracted some 3,500 visitors while the museum was still under construction.<ref>Kelly Crow (May 26, 2015), [https://www.wsj.com/articles/eli-and-edythe-broad-build-a-museum-for-their-art-collection-1432648768 Eli and Edythe Broad Build a Museum for Their Art Collection] ''[[WSJ.]]''.</ref> The museum opened by Broad and his wife on Sunday, September 20, 2015.<ref name=WPproblemwith>{{cite news|author=Philip Kennicott |title=The problem with The Broad is the collection itself |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/museums/the-problem-with-the-broad-is-the-collection-itself/2015/09/13/05503400-5a4e-11e5-b38e-06883aacba64_story.html |work=The Washington Post |date=September 19, 2015 |accessdate=September 20, 2015}}</ref> To date, it has received more than 1.2 million visitors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thebroad.org/about|title=The Broad|website=thebroad.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-08}}</ref>
====Grand Avenue project==== Broad founded the Grand Avenue Committee, which coordinates and oversees development of [[Grand Avenue (Los Angeles)|Grand Avenue]] in [[downtown Los Angeles]]. In 1996, Broad and [[Mayor of Los Angeles|Los Angeles Mayor]] [[Richard Riordan]] led the fundraising campaign to build the [[Frank Gehry]]-designed [[Walt Disney Concert Hall]], which opened in October 2003. Broad was instrumental in securing the $50 million deposit from the project developer that opened [[Grand Park]] in summer 2012.
[[File:The Broad Art Museum, East Lansing, Michigan USA.JPG|thumb|The Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum at 547 East Circle Drive, Michigan State University, East Lansing, Michigan USA]]
====Higher education philanthropic work==== Broad’s first civic board membership and significant investment in education was a $10 million commitment to [[Pitzer College]] in 1970. He was eventually named chairman of the board.
In 1991, Broad endowed the [[Eli Broad College of Business]] and the [[Eli Broad College of Business|Eli Broad Graduate School of Management]] with $20 million for a full-time [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] program at his alma mater, [[Michigan State University]].<ref name="History of the Broad College"> {{cite web | url = http://broad.msu.edu/information/history/ | title = History of the Broad College | accessdate = September 18, 2013 }} </ref> The couple gave $5 million to endow the Eli and Edythe L. Broad Dean of Business.
In 2000, Broad gave $23.2 million for the Broad Art Center at [[UCLA]], designed by [[Richard Meier]].<ref name="Website of Richard Meier with commission">{{cite web | url = http://www.richardmeier.com/?projects=ucla-eli-edythe-broad-art-center-2 | title = Website of Richard Meier | accessdate = June 22, 2016 }} </ref> Eli and Edythe Broad donated $28 million to Michigan State University for the construction of the [[Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum]], designed by [[Pritzker Architecture Prize]]-winning [[architect]] [[Zaha Hadid]]. The museum opened in November 2012.
===Scientific and medical research=== The Broads’ investments in scientific and medical research focus on three areas: [[Genomics|human genomics]], [[stem cell research]] and [[inflammatory bowel disease]] (IBD).
In 2001, the Broads created the Broad Medical Research Program to fund innovative research to advance the treatment of IBD.
In 2003, Eli and Edythe Broad gave the $100 million founding gift to create The [[Broad Institute]] of [[MIT]] and [[Harvard]]. The following year, they gave another $100 million, and in 2009, they gave another $400 million to create an endowment to make the institute permanent.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/05/education/05gift.html?hp | work=The New York Times | title=$400 Million Gift to Genetic Institute | first=Stephanie | last=Strom | date=September 5, 2008 | accessdate=May 1, 2010}}</ref> The Broads announced Nov. 14, 2013, they were giving an additional $100 million to the institute.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.broadinstitute.org/news/5346 | work=The Broad Institute | title=Broad Institute launches next decade with new $100M gift | accessdate=November 14, 2013}}</ref> The Broad Institute is now the leading genomic medicine institute, employing 2,000 people with an annual research budget of $287 million.<ref>{{cite news| title=How Eli Broad gives his billions away|date=2011-04-24|accessdate=2015-10-27|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/video/watch/?id=7363716n | publisher=[[CBS News]]}}</ref> To date, the Broads have given $800 million to the Institute.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://broadfoundation.org/10th-anniversary-three-broad-funded-california-stem-cell-research-centers-broad-foundation-announces-1-million-fund-innovative-pilot-research-ucla-ucsf-usc/|title=On 10th Anniversary of Three Broad-Funded California Stem Cell Research Centers, Broad Foundation Announces $1 Million to Fund Innovative Pilot Research at UCLA, UCSF, USC {{!}} The Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation|date=2017-02-03|work=The Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation|access-date=2017-08-08|language=en-US}}</ref>
The Eli and Edythe Broad Center for Regenerative Medicine and Stem Cell Research at [[University of Southern California|USC]] is the product of a public-private partnership between voter-created [[California Institute for Regenerative Medicine|California Institute of Regenerative Medicine]], the [[Keck School of Medicine of USC]] and the Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation, which donated $30 million in 2006.<ref>{{cite web |last=Lewit |first=Meghan |url=http://www.usc.edu/uscnews/stories/15561.html |title=USC breaks ground on cutting-edge stem cell center |publisher=Usc.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-04-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526155011/http://www.usc.edu/uscnews/stories/15561.html |archivedate=2011-05-26 |df= }}</ref> In 2007, the Broads also donated $20 million to the UCLA Stem Cell Institute.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.stemcell.ucla.edu |title=UCLA Stem Cell Institute website|date= |accessdate=2016-06-22}}</ref> One year later, they gave a major gift to the [[University of California, San Francisco]] for the new headquarters of the Eli and Edythe Broad Center of Regeneration Medicine and Stem Cell Research, which opened in February 2011. Broad is also a member of the [[California Institute of Technology]] Board of Trustees where he funded the Broad Center for the Biological Sciences. In 2009, the Broads gave $5 million to fund the Joint Center for Translational Medicine at [[Caltech]] and [[UCLA]].
===Gun control=== In August 2013, Broad donated $250,000 to oppose the recalls of Colorado Senate President John Morse and Sen. Angela Giron, who were being recalled for their support of gun control measures, including a ban on magazines of 15 rounds or more.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stokols|first=Eli|title=Bloomberg gives $350K to Morse, Giron recall defense|url=http://kdvr.com/2013/08/27/bloomberg-gives-350k-to-morse-girons-recall-defense/|newspaper=KDVR Denver|date=2013-08-27|quote=Billionaire Eli Broad also wrote a $250,000 check to the organization, which raised a total of $708,000 in contributions between April and Aug. 22.}}</ref>
==Art collection== Broad’s interest in art began in 1973 with his family’s first acquisition of a [[Van Gogh]] drawing, entitled "Cabanes a Saintes-Maries" (1888).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.flashartonline.com/interno.php?pagina=articolo_det&id_art=469&det=ok&title=ELI-BROAD |title=Eli Broad |publisher=Flash Art |date= |accessdate=2011-04-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711011211/http://www.flashartonline.com/interno.php?pagina=articolo_det&id_art=469&det=ok&title=ELI-BROAD |archivedate=2011-07-11 |df= }}</ref> Art collector and [[MCA Records|MCA]] executive Taft Schreiber<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jan/16/entertainment/la-ca-broad-simon-20110116 | title=Eli Broad, today's Norton Simon | work=Los Angeles Times | first1=Christopher | last1=Knight | date=January 16, 2011}}</ref> became his mentor. The Broads' early acquisitions included notable works by [[Miró]], [[Picasso]] and [[Matisse]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Aspden |first=Peter |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/4e3eb722-ca62-11de-a3a3-00144feabdc0.html#ixzz1BOeEJJdP |title=Putting LA at the heart of world culture |work=Financial Times |date=November 6, 2009 |accessdate=2011-04-25}}</ref> Eventually, the pair began to concentrate on post–World War II art.<ref>{{cite web |last=Palmeri |first=Christopher |url=http://www.businessweek.com/bwdaily/dnflash/oct2001/nf20011029_1083.htm |title=Art Collecting, Eli Broad Style |work=Businessweek |date=October 29, 2001 |accessdate=2011-04-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111105235252/http://www.businessweek.com/bwdaily/dnflash/oct2001/nf20011029_1083.htm |archivedate=November 5, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Eli and Edythe Broad established The Broad Art Foundation in 1984 with the goal of making their extensive contemporary art collection more accessible to the public; to date The Foundation has made more than 8,000 loans to more than 500 [[Art museum|museums and university galleries]] worldwide.
The Broads have two collections—a personal collection with nearly 600 works and The Broad Art Foundation's collection, which has approximately 1,500 works [[modern art|Modern]] and [[contemporary art]]. In January 2008, the Broads decided that works in their personal collection would ultimately go to their foundation to make the artwork accessible to the public through the foundation’s loan program.
Some of the best-known works are by contemporary artists including:<ref name="latimes01102008">{{Cite news|last=Knight |first=Christopher |author-link= |title=Will LACMA's reputation suffer from Broad's change of heart? |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=January 10, 2008 |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/arts/la-et-critic11jan10,1,6451548.story?ctrack=4&cset=true |format=– <sup>[https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=author%3AKnight+intitle%3AWill+LACMA%27s+reputation+suffer+from+Broad%27s+change+of+heart%3F&as_publication=&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]</sup> |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117104327/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/arts/la-et-critic11jan10,1,6451548.story?ctrack=4&cset=true |archivedate=January 17, 2008 }}</ref>
* [[John Baldessari]]'s two text paintings from 1967–68. * [[Jasper Johns]] – flag paintings (1960 and 1967), mixed-media "Watchman" (1964), "hatch" (1975) * [[Jeff Koons]] – fluorescent-lighted vacuum cleaners (1981), floating basketballs and bronze lifeboat (both 1985), stainless-steel bunny rabbit (1986), "Bubbles," a life-size porcelain portrait of Michael Jackson and his pet chimpanzee (1988) bought on May 15, 2001 for 5.6M,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sothebys.com/app/live/lot/LotDetail.jsp?lot_id=38SNB |title=Sotheby's – Auctions – Calendar – Contemporary Art Part One |publisher=Sothebys.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-25}}{{dead link|date=August 2012}}</ref> the first "Balloon Dog" (1994, in blue), and a "Cracked Egg" purchased for $3.5 million in 2006. Broad owns more than 20 Koons pieces, and donated €640,000 ($900,000) to help sponsor a 2008 Koons retrospective at [[Palace of Versailles|Versailles]] (with fellow Koons collector [[François Pinault]]).<ref>{{cite news|publisher=ArtNews|date=November 2008|title=Where Michael Jackson Meets Louis XIV: How the Jeff Koons exhibition at Versailles led to a national controversy in France|first=Richard|last=Covington}} ARTNews, Nov. 2008, p. 104: "One of the main sponsors helping to defray that cost was Pinault, who, officials say, contributed about €960,000 toward the exhibition's €1.9 million ($2.6 million) total cost. (Other private sponsors, including Los Angeles property developers Eli and Edythe Broad, who count more than 20 Koons pieces in their collection, contributed €640,000 [$900,000], and the state chipped in €300,000 [$400,000], according to Versailles officials.)"</ref> * [[Roy Lichtenstein]] – three comic strip paintings (1962–65) and his 1969 abstraction of a mirror. In November 1994, Broad purchased "I...I'm Sorry" for $2.5 million [[United States dollar|USD]] at a [[Sotheby's]] auction, paid with his [[American Express]] [[credit card]], and thereby earned 2.5 million [[Frequent flyer program|frequent flyer miles]]. * [[Robert Rauschenberg]] – 1954 red abstraction. * [[Damien Hirst]] – Away From the Flock.<ref> [http://www.lacma.org/press/releases/bcamf.pdf LACMA Press release], accessed, December 12, 2010 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205063754/http://www.lacma.org/press/releases/bcamf.pdf |date=December 5, 2010 }}</ref> * [[Edward Ruscha]]'s first word painting, "Boss" (1961) and his 1964 picture of [[Norms Restaurants|Norm's]] [[La Cienega Boulevard]] restaurant on fire. * [[Cindy Sherman]] – twelve photographs from 1977–150 photographs. The Broads have the world’s largest collection of Sherman’s works. * [[David Smith (sculptor)|David Smith]] – [[Cubi|Cubi XXVIII]], executed in 1965. Broad's October 2005 purchase at a [[Sotheby's]] auction set a contemporary art auction record of $23,816,000. Broad claimed he had "been looking for a [[Cubi]] for more than a decade...I knew it would go way over the estimate and I was prepared, frankly, to pay more than what I bid." {{citation needed|date=September 2013}} * [[Andy Warhol]]'s advertising image, "Where's your rupture?", two [[Marilyn Monroe]] images, a twenty-fold silkscreen of [[Jackie Kennedy]], an [[Elvis]], a dance diagram, a wanted poster, an electric chair and a torn [[Campbell's Soup Cans|Campbell's soup can]]—pepper pot (purchased for $11.8 million) – all from 1961 to 1967.
==Honors and awards== From 2004 to 2009, Broad served as a regent of the [[Smithsonian Institution]] by appointment of the [[U.S. Congress]] and the president.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://capitolwords.org/date/2004/07/20/H6082_providing-for-appointment-of-eli-broad-as-citizen-/|title=Providing For Appointment Of Eli Broad As Citizen Regent Of Board Of Regents Of Smithsonian Institution|work=Capitol Words|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130904221645/http://capitolwords.org/date/2004/07/20/H6082_providing-for-appointment-of-eli-broad-as-citizen-/|archivedate=2013-09-04|df=}}</ref> He is a Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] and in 1994 was named Chevalier in the National Order of the [[Legion of Honor]] by the [[Republic of France]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=Broad Impact: An Interview with Eli Broad, Founder, The Broad Foundations |journal=Leaders |date=2012 |volume=35 |issue=2 |page=36 |url=http://leadersmag.com/issues/2012.2_apr/Shaping%20the%20Future/LEADERS-Eli-Broad-The-Broad-Foundations.html}}</ref> Broad serves on the board of the Future Generation Art Prize.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.futuregenerationartprize.org/about/pressrelease |title=Second edition of the Victor Pinchuk Foundation’s $100,000 Future Generation Art Prize is announced |work=Future Generation Art Prize|date=February 6, 2012|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004223717/http://www.futuregenerationartprize.org/about/pressrelease |archivedate=2013-10-04 |df= }}</ref> He received the Carnegie Medal of Philanthropy in 2007<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.carnegiemedals.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=42:four-families-honored-with-carnegie-medal-for-enlightened-giving&catid=15:news|title=Carnegie Medals|author=Super User|work=carnegiemedals.org}}</ref> and the [[David Rockefeller]] Award from the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in March 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://panacheprivee.com/Web/BeSeen/MoMARockefeller09/David_Rockefeller_Award_Luncheon.asp|title=MoMA David Rockefeller Award Luncheon, New York - People & Parties With Panache|work=panacheprivee.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005015436/http://panacheprivee.com/Web/BeSeen/MoMARockefeller09/David_Rockefeller_Award_Luncheon.asp|archivedate=2013-10-05|df=}}</ref> In October 2013, the Broads were awarded the [[William E. Simon Prize for Philanthropic Leadership]] by [[Philanthropy Roundtable]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philanthropyroundtable.org/topic/excellence_in_philanthropy/winners_of_the_2013_william_e._simon_prize|title=Winners of the 2013 William E. Simon Prize|work=philanthropyroundtable.org}}</ref>
==Controversy== {{POV section|date=February 2017}} In 2013, Eli Broad was named by the California attorney general as a contributor to Americans for Job Security, a Virginia trade association. The money sent to Americans for Job Security was intended for "issue advocacy," meaning advertising that doesn't expressly urge Californians to vote one way or another. However, Americans for Job Security sent some of their donations to a Phoenix group, Americans for Responsible Leadership, which provided it to a small business action committee that opposed [[California Proposition 30 (2012)|Proposition 30]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/oct/25/local/la-me-secret-money-20131025 | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Chris | last=Megerian | title=California fines groups $16 million for funneling money to campaigns | date=October 25, 2013}}</ref> It is unclear whether Eli Broad was aware that his 2013 donation would be used in this way, since he had stated in 2012 that he supported higher taxes on the wealthy.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2012/01/philanthropist-broad-endorses-browns-call-for-raising-taxes.html | work=Los Angeles Times | title=L.A. Now | date=January 18, 2012}}</ref>
In 2015, the Los Angeles Times obtained a secret 44-page proposal <ref>{{cite news| url=http://documents.latimes.com/great-public-schools-now-initiative | work=Los Angeles Times | title=The Great Public Schools Now Initiative | date=September 21, 2015}}</ref> drafted by the Eli and Edythe Broad Foundation and other charter advocates (including several other billionaires) that was designed to charterize 50% of LA public schools. According to one unnamed critic at portside.org, such an outcome would "do away with democratically controlled, publicly accountable education in LA." <ref>{{cite news| url=http://portside.org/2015-09-26/billionaire%E2%80%99s-secret-plan-%E2%80%98hostile-takeover%E2%80%99-la-public-schools#sthash.RRCidnDj.dpuf | work=Portside | title=Billionaire’s Secret Plan: A ‘Hostile Takeover’ of LA Public Schools | date=September 23, 2015}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{advert|date=July 2016}} [[File:GIST Logo.jpg|thumbnail]] The '''Global Innovation through Science and Technology initiative''' ('''GIST''') is a U.S. government program on innovation and entrepreneurship. The program assists businesspeople to establish startups. GIST participants in 135 emerging economies can develop skills, build networks, find mentors, and access financing through a combination of in-country training, a pitch competition, interactive online programming, and direct connections to U.S. experts. GIST helps create conditions for successful local entrepreneurship ecosystems and enables global youth to develop local solutions to local problems. GIST is also one of the key programs under President Obama's SPARK Initiative, an initiative under which programs are selected to represent the best work being done by the U.S. Government to advance entrepreneurship around the world.
Since 2011, GIST has engaged more than 2.8 million innovators and entrepreneurs worldwide and mentored over 5,000 startups that have generated more than $110 million in revenue. GIST is a partnership led by the [[U.S. Department of State]]'s [[Bureau of Oceans and International Environmental and Scientific Affairs]], with implementation of programs by [[Venturewell]] and the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] (AAAS).
==Launch == The GIST programs were announced at the 2011 conference on Economic Development through Science and Technology Innovation in Rabat, Morocco attended by U.S. [[Assistant Secretary of State for Oceans and International Environmental and Scientific Affairs]] Dr. Kerri-Ann Jones. This conference was the third and final consultative meeting to develop high impact engagement opportunities. Previous meetings were held in Alexandria, Egypt and Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.<ref>{{cite news|title=GIST Initiative Launches Innovation and Entrepreneurship Programs|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2011/06/166490.htm|agency=U.S. Department of State|publisher=Office of the Spokesperson|date=18 Jun 2011}}</ref> The GIST initiative exemplifies a science and technology innovation partnership that U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] called for in a 2009 speech at [[Cairo University]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Remarks by the President at Cairo University|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/Remarks-by-the-President-at-Cairo-University-6-04-09|website=White House|accessdate=16 July 2014}}</ref>
GIST assists entrepeneurs in 135 emerging economies through its Global Online Innovation Community, including online programming and mentorship; in-country training programs, the GIST Startup Boot Camps, GIST Ideation Boot Camps and GIST Villages; and the annual GIST Tech-I Global Pitch Competition.
==Global Online Innovation Community==
GISTNetwork is a government program led by the Department of State that provides a user-driven online resource to help young science and technology entrepreneurs in emerging economies build viable startups. GISTNetwork connects entrepreneurs to peers, mentors, experts, and financing both globally and within their communities.
GISTNetwork’s online community provides: Mentors from top U.S. universities, Silicon Valley startups and local communities around the world; live and on-demand programming, including pages focused on specific local communities; and access to international angel investors and venture capitalists and a meeting place to find entrepreneurial team members.
==GIST Online Programming==
GIST online programming provides in-country entrepreneurs with direct online access to U.S. businesspeople and academics. The two key online programs are the GIST TechConnect and GIST Guru Series.
==GIST In-Country Training Programs== GIST in-country programs nurture the next generation of innovators and entrepreneurs through direct, on-the-ground training. Top U.S. and in-country leaders teach and mentor aspiring entrepreneurs, who also develop financial know-how and access to capital that allow them to advance their science and technology ventures with skill and confidence. There are three main in-country programs: GIST Ideation Boot Camps; GIST Startup Boot Camps; and GIST Villages.
==GIST Tech-I Global Pitch Competition==
The GIST Tech-I Global Pitch Competition is an annual competition for science and technology entrepreneurs from emerging economies worldwide. Participants produce videos to pitch their ideas and startups, which are reviewed first by a panel of experts and then by the online voting public. Finalists receive a trip to the Global Entrepreneurship Summit (GES), three months of one-to-one mentoring, and the chance to win seed capital. Through two days of intensive training and pitching their ventures at the GES, GIST Tech-I finalists make connections and gain international exposure.
Since 2011, innovators from over 100 emerging economies have showcased their science and technology ventures through GIST Tech-I Global Pitch Competitions, with over one million votes from the online voting public.
The first Tech-I competition occurred in 2011 in Istanbul, Turkey. Notable Tech-I finalists have included Nermin Sa'd, founder of Hanadisayat.net from Jordan;<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ghazal|first1=Mohammad|title=Mechanical engineers, mothers work from home to keep career passion alive|url=http://jordantimes.com/mechanical-engineers-mothers-work-from-home-to-keep-career-passion-alive|accessdate=4 August 2014|publisher=Jordan Times|date=30 Dec 2013}}</ref> and Natali Ardianto, founder and COO of Tiket.com from Indonesia.<ref>{{cite news|title=Top Global Emerging Startups Showcase at D.C. DEMO Day June 18 as Part of ‘GIST Entrepreneurship Journey’|url=http://www.newswise.com/articles/top-global-emerging-startups-showcase-at-d-c-demo-day-june-18-as-part-of-gist-entrepreneurship-journey|accessdate=4 August 2014|agency=Newswise|date=16 Jun 2014}}</ref>
The Tech-I Competition of the GIST initiative is implemented by the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] (AAAS).<ref>{{cite web|title=Tech-I Program Announcement|url=http://www.aaas.org/sites/default/files/reports/TechI_Program_Announcement_FINAL.pdf|website=American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS)|publisher=AAAS|accessdate=15 Jul 2014}}</ref>

[[File:Weber's model of capitalist development.svg|thumb|300px|Max Weber's model of capitalist development]] The '''history of capitalism''' has diverse and much debated roots, but fully-fledged [[capitalism]] is generally thought to have emerged in north-west Europe, especially in the [[Low Countries]] (mainly present-day [[Flanders]] and [[Netherlands]]) and [[Great Britain|Britain]], in the sixteenth to seventeenth centuries. Over the following centuries, [[Capital (economics)|capital]] has been accumulated by a variety of different methods, in a variety of scales, and associated with a great deal of variation in the concentration of economic power and wealth, and capitalism has gradually become the dominant economic system throughout the world.<ref name="Scott 2005">Scott (2005)</ref> Much of the history of the past five hundred years is, therefore, concerned with the development of capitalism in its various forms.
==Varieties of capitalism== It is an ongoing debate within the fields of economics and sociology as to what the past, current and future stages of capitalism consist of. While ongoing disagreement about exact stages exists, many economists have posited the following general states. These states are not mutually exclusive and do not represent a fixed order of historical change, but do represent a broadly chronological trend. * ''[[Laissez-faire]]'' capitalism, a social system in which the government is exclusively devoted to the protection of individual rights, including property rights – one in which there exists absolutely no government intervention in the economy. * Agrarian capitalism, sometimes known as market feudalism. This was a transitional form between feudalism and capitalism, whereby market relations replaced some but not all of feudal relations in a society. * [[Mercantilism]], where national governments sought to maintain positive balances of trade and acquire gold bullion. * [[Industrial capitalism]], characterized by its use of heavy machinery and a much more pronounced division of labor. * [[Monopoly capitalism]], marked by the rise of monopolies and trusts dominating industry as well as other aspects of society. Often used to describe the economy of the late 19th and early 20th century. * [[Colonialism]], where governments sought to colonize other areas to improve access to markets and raw materials and improve the standing of nationally based capitalist firms. Predominant in the 1890s, notably as a response to the economic crises of the 1890s. * [[Welfare capitalism]], where mixed economies predominated and governments sought to provide a safety net to alleviate the worst abuses of capitalism. The heyday of welfare capitalism (in advanced economies) is widely seen to be from 1945 to 1973 as major social safety nets were put in place in most advanced capitalist economies.<ref name="A People pg. 251-397">"A People's History of the World" Chris Harman pp. 251–397</ref> * [[Mass production]], post-World War II, saw the rising hegemony of major corporations and a focus on mass production, mass consumption and (ideally) mass employment. This stage sees the rise of advertising as a way to promote mass consumption and often sees significant economic planning taking place within firms.<ref name="ReferenceB">"The New Industrial State" J.K. Galbraith pp. 16–35</ref> * [[State capitalism]], where the state intervened to prevent economic instability, including partially or fully nationalizing certain industries. Some economists also include the economies of the [[Soviet Union]] and the [[Eastern Bloc]] in this category.<ref name="Michael Barratt 1974 pp. 309–30: Chapter 12">"The Economics of Imperialism" [[Michael Barratt Brown]] pp. 309–30 (Chapter12)</ref> * [[Corporatism]], where government, business and labor collude to make major national decisions. Notable for being an economic model of fascism, it can overlap with, but is still significantly different from state capitalism. * [[Financialization]], or [[financial capitalism]], where financial parts of the economy (like the finance, insurance, or real estate sectors) predominate in an economy. Profit becomes more derived from ownership of an asset, credit, rents and earning interest, rather than actual productive processes.<ref name="ReferenceC">"Zombie Capitalism" Chris Harman pp. 142–60</ref><ref>Marois, Thomas (2012) "Finance, Finance Capital, and Financialisation." In: Fine, Ben and Saad Filho, Alfredo, (eds.), ''The Elgar Companion to Marxist Economics''. Cheltenham: Edward Elgar.</ref>
==Historiography== The processes by which capitalism came about, evolved, and spread, are the subject of extensive research and debate among historians. Debates sometimes circle around how ''capitalism'' is defined, but a significant body of work has been able to bring substantive historical data to bear on key questions.<ref>Richard Biernacki, review of Ellen Meiksins Wood (1999), ''[[The Origin of Capitalism]]'' (Monthly Review Press, 1999), in ''Contemporary Sociology,'' Vol. 29, No. 4 (Jul., 2000), pp. 638–39 {{JSTOR|2654574}}.</ref> Key parameters of debate include: how far capitalism is a natural human behaviour and how far it arises from specific historical circumstances; whether its origins lie in towns and trade or in rural property relations; the role of class conflict; the role of the state; how far it is a distinctively European innovation; its relationship with European imperialism; whether technological change is a driver or merely an epiphenomenon of capitalism; and whether or not it is the most beneficial way to organise human societies.<ref name="Ellen Meiksins Wood 2002">Ellen Meiksins Wood (2002), ''[[The Origin of Capitalism: A Longer View]]'' (London: Verso, 2002).</ref>
The historiography of capitalism can be divided into two broad schools. One is associated with [[economic liberalism]], with the eighteenth-century economist [[Adam Smith]] as a foundational figure, and one with [[Marxism]], drawing particular inspiration from the nineteenth-century economist [[Karl Marx]]. Liberals tend to view capitalism as an expression of natural human behaviours which have been in evidence for millennia, and the most beneficial way of promoting human wellbeing. They tend to see capitalism as originating in trade and commerce, and freeing people to exercise their entrepreneurial natures. Marxists tend to view capitalism as a historically unusual system of relationships between classes, which could be replaced by other economic systems which would serve human wellbeing better. They tend to see capitalism as originating in more powerful people taking control of the means of production, and compelling others to sell their labour as a commodity.<ref name="Ellen Meiksins Wood 2002"/> For these reasons, much of the work on the history of capitalism has been [[Marxist historiography|broadly Marxist]].{{citation needed|date=October 2018}}
=== Origins of capitalism === The origins of capitalism have been much debated (and depend partly on how the defining features of capitalism are defined). The traditional account, originating in classical eighteenth-century liberal economic thought and still often articulated, is the 'commercialization model'. This sees capitalism originating in trade. Since evidence for trade is found even in palaeolithic culture, it can be seen as natural to human societies. In this reading, capitalism emerged from earlier trade once merchants had acquired sufficient wealth (referred to as '[[primitive capital]]') to begin investing in increasingly productive technology. This account tends to see capitalism as a natural continuation of trade, arising when people's natural entrepreneurialism was freed from the constraints of [[feudalism]], partly by urbanization.<ref>Ellen Meiksins Wood (2002), ''The Origin of Capitalism: A Longer View'' (London: Verso, 2002.), pp. 11–21.</ref> Thus it traces capitalism to early forms of [[merchant capitalism]] practiced in Western Europe during the [[Middle Ages]].<ref name="Banaji">Jairus Banaji (2007), "Islam, the Mediterranean and the rise of capitalism", ''Journal Historical Materialism'' 15#1 pp. 47–74, Brill Publishers.</ref>
