{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2012}} The '''Potomac-Appalachian Transmission Highline''' (PATH) was a proposed 290 mile 765 kilovolt<ref name="Allegheny-Energy-May-2008-10-Q">{{cite web|url=http://pdf.secdatabase.com/2353/0000950152-08-003587.pdf |title=Allegheny Energy, Form 10-Q, Quarterly Report, Filing Date May 7, 2008 |publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =Jan 6, 2013}}</ref> [[electric power transmission]] line designed to supply power from the Amos Substation located in [[Putnam County, West Virginia|Putnam County]], West Virginia, to a proposed [[electrical substation]] to be constructed in [[Frederick County, Maryland|Frederick County]], Maryland.<ref name="Allegheny-Energy-Feb-2011-10-K">{{cite web|url=http://edgar.secdatabase.com/2109/119312511043729/filing-main.htm |title=Allegheny Energy, Form 10-K, Annual Report, Filing Date Feb 23, 2011 |publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =Jan 6, 2013}}</ref> If approved, the transmission line would have been owned and operated by subsidiary companies of [[Allegheny Energy]] and the [[American Electric Power|American Electric Power Company]]. The route proposed would have gone through 13 counties in [[West Virginia]], three counties in [[Virginia]], and Frederick County in [[Maryland]].<ref>[http://www.pathtransmission.com/maps/ Potomac-Appalachian Transmission Highline: Maps] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090720094143/http://www.pathtransmission.com/maps/ |date=July 20, 2009 }}</ref> The endpoint in Maryland would be a proposed electrical substation in Kemptown, MD, that would be in a residential area surrounded by about 1,300 houses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.istockanalyst.com/article/viewiStockNews/articleid/3925878 |title=Residents step up battle against PATH substation |publisher=Istockanalyst.com |date=March 6, 2010 |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref> The Kemptown substation would have been the largest substation ever built by Allegheny Power.<ref>{{cite web|author=FNP Interactive - http://www.fnpInteractive.com |url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/sections/news/display.htm?StoryID=110524 |title=Large turnout expected to oppose substation at zoning meeting |publisher=Fredericknewspost.com |date=September 29, 2010 |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref> The project was cancelled by [[PJM Interconnection]] in 2011.<ref name=cancelled>{{cite web|url=http://pjm.com/~/media/documents/reports/20110228-bom-statement-planning-for-transmission.ashx |title=Statement of Terry Boston, President and CEO, on behalf of the PJM Board of Managers |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref>
==Application status==
=== 2009 === Initial applications for regulatory approval to construct the PATH transmission line were filed in 2009. On September 9, 2009, the [[Maryland Public Service Commission]] rejected the application as improperly filed.<ref>[http://www.wvpubcast.org/newsarticle.aspx?id=11221 West Virginia Public Broadcasting, "PATH rejected by Maryland PSC on technicalities"].</ref> PATH was given 30 days to declare whether they would refile in Maryland, but only announced they were reconsidering their options. On October 19, 2009, the [[Virginia State Corporation Commission]] filed a motion to dismiss the PATH application in Virginia, citing inability to adequately analyze the project due to an uncertain Maryland termination point.<ref>[http://leesburgtoday.com/articles/2009/10/23/news/fp11path102009.txt ''Leesburg Today'', "SCC Staff Recommends PATH Application Dismissal"].</ref> On October 28, 2009 an attorney for the [[West Virginia Public Service Commission]] moved to dismiss the PATH application in West Virginia. Virginia and West Virginia are requesting rejection of the application [[without prejudice]], meaning PATH will be able to refile in those states once they have refiled a proper application in Maryland.<ref>[http://journal-news.net/page/content.detail/id/527158.html?startIndex=26 [[The Journal (West Virginia newspaper)|The Journal]], "PSC seeks to halt PATH"].</ref>
=== 2010 === Allegheny Power filed applications with Frederick County for a special exception to locate an electric power substation in agricultural zoned land. On September 15 they met with the Frederick County Planning Commission make a case that this is consistent with the [http://www.frederickcountymd.gov/index.aspx?NID=170 Frederick County Comprehensive Plan].<ref name="nokemptownsubstation308">{{cite web|author=Aug 16 |url=http://www.nokemptownsubstation.org/?p=308 |title=Citizens Against the Kemptown Substation Website, "URGENT: Must-Attend Hearings" |publisher=Nokemptownsubstation.org |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref> The commission found a substation of this size and at this location to be "inconsistent with the county's comprehensive plan."<ref>{{cite web|author=FNP Interactive - http://www.fnpInteractive.com |url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/sections/news/display.htm?StoryID=109976 |title=Frederick News-Post, "Planning commission finds substation plans lacking" |publisher=Fredericknewspost.com |date=September 16, 2010 |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref> On September 29, 2010, there was a hearing for the Frederick County Board of Zoning Appeals at which PATH will submit a special exception zoning request.<ref name="nokemptownsubstation308"/><ref>{{cite web|author=FNP Interactive - http://www.fnpInteractive.com |url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/sections/news/display.htm?StoryID=110568 |title=Crisis at substation could be a major problem for firefighters |publisher=Fredericknewspost.com |date=September 30, 2010 |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref> After several hearings, on November 18, 2010, the application for a special exception was denied.<ref>{{cite web|author=FNP Interactive - http://www.fnpInteractive.com |url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/sections/news/display.htm?storyid=112640 |title=Frederick News-Post, "PATH substation near Mount Airy denied in zoning vote" |publisher=Fredericknewspost.com |date=November 19, 2010 |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=FNP Interactive - http://www.fnpInteractive.com |url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/sections/news/display.htm?StoryID=112640 |title=Gazette.net, "PATH substation near Mount Airy denied in zoning vote" |publisher=Fredericknewspost.com |date=November 19, 2010 |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref> On December 20, 2010, Allegheny Power asked the Frederick County Board of Appeals to reconsider, and the board denied this request.<ref>{{cite web|author=FNP Interactive - http://www.fnpInteractive.com |url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/sections/business/display.htm?StoryID=113983 |title=Frederick News-Post, "Board won't reconsider substation denial" |publisher=Fredericknewspost.com |date=December 21, 2010 |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gazette.net/stories/12212010/frednew113559_32578.php |title=PATH reconsideration request denied |publisher=Gazette.net |date=December 21, 2010 |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref>
Regional grid manager, PJM Interconnection, "has several times shifted the date by which the line must be in service to address overloads, from 2012 to 2013 and 2014 and, most recently, to June 2015."<ref>[http://www.wtrf.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=91437 wtrf.com, "PATH Transmission Line Applicants Propose Fourth Extension of Timeline"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726071823/http://www.wtrf.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=91437 |date=July 26, 2011 }}</ref> On December 20, 2010, Allegheny Energy and AEP requested a procedural delay with the Public Service Commission of West Virginia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20101220-711937.html |title=Wall Street Journal, "PATH Seeks Delay In Transmission Line Proceeding In West Virginia" |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=December 20, 2010 |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://www.tradingmarkets.com/news/stock-alert/aye_aep_allegheny-energy-and-american-electric-power-seeks-delay-in-path-project-in-virginia-1380521.html tradingmarkets.com, "Allegheny Energy and American Electric Power seeks delay in PATH project in Virginia"]{{dead link|date=January 2012}}</ref>
=== 2011 === On February 28, 2011 PJM Interconnect requested that [[FirstEnergy]] (which took control of Allegheny Power on February 25, 2011) and American Electric Power suspend efforts on PATH. "Recent dramatic swings in economic forecasts and evolving public policies, particularly with respect to renewable energy, are adding greater uncertainty to our planning studies," PJM President and CEO Terry Boston said in a prepared statement.<ref name=cancelled /> American Electric Power's and FirstEnergy Corp withdrew applications for the project in Maryland, Virginia, and West Virginia.<ref>{{cite web|author=BRIAN FARKAS Associated Press |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory?id=13021919 |title=ABC News, "$2B Power Line Project From WVa to Md. Suspended" |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date=March 1, 2011 |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref><ref name="fredericknewspost1">{{cite web|author=FNP Interactive - http://www.fnpInteractive.com |url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/sections/news/display.htm?StoryID=117464 |title=Frederick News Post, "PATH applications withdrawn in three states; opponents elated" |publisher=Fredericknewspost.com |date=March 1, 2011 |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref>
Dick Ishler, President of the Citizens Against the Kemptown Electrical Substation (CAKES) says this is a huge victory for the little guy; "This is but the latest example of David beating Goliath, concerned citizens banding together, in this case, to stop a toxic coal-fired transmission line."<ref name="fredericknewspost1"/> Will Burns, the Sierra Club attorney who has spent hundreds of hours researching the PATH project is optimistic PJM's order will close the PATH project down; "We didn't believe this was needed for reliability reasons. We're hoping this will be the last time this will come back again."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.tradingcharts.com/futures/7/2/154215327.html |title=tradingcharts.com, "PATH project temporarily suspended by regional grid operator" |publisher=News.tradingcharts.com |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref> However, PJM could revise the decision at a later time, and the PATH project could be renewed.<ref name="fredericknewspost1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.58wchs.com/includes/news_items/7/news_items_more.php?id=3820&section_id=7 |title=PATH Opponent Will Stay Vigilant |publisher=58wchs.com |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref> “If they [PJM] come back and say we need PATH, then we can get the project back up and running. . . . The investment we’ve already made won’t be lost though, because the project is not lost – just suspended,” said Doug Colafella, manager of external communications for FirstEnergy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedailyrecord.com/2011/04/13/path-power-line-project-all-but-out-of-juice/ |title=PATH power line project all but out of juice |publisher=Thedailyrecord.com |date=April 13, 2011 |accessdate=January 12, 2012}}</ref>
=== 2012 === In August 2012, "the board of PJM Interconnection, which oversees the needs and movement of wholesale electricity in the region, formally removed the project from future plans."<ref name="Jersey-Central-Power-Light-Dec-2012-10-Q">{{cite web|url=http://pdf.secdatabase.com/1697/0001407703-12-000003.pdf |title=Jersey Central Power Light, Form 10-Q, Quarterly Report, Filing Date Dec 11, 2012 |publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =Jan 6, 2013}}</ref><ref>[http://www.fredericknewspost.com/sections/news/display.htm?StoryID=139947#.UDz6_KO051Y Board order formally ends PATH project]</ref>
== Kemptown Property == {{References|date=April 2018}} In December 2008 PATH Allegheny Transmission Company, LLC purchased two contiguous properties in Kemptown, Maryland comprising 152.2 acres for $6.83 million. The properties, actively farmed at the time, were sold by the Browning family which held title to one property as a limited partnership and the other property as a limited liability company. The Kemptown properties are bisected by a high tension electrical transmission line owned by the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company and are adjacent to a second high tension electrical transmission line. PATH planned to The Kemptown property was slated by PATH as the location of a large electrical substation. In September 2010, PATH Allegheny Transmission Company, LLC conveyed the property to PATH Allegheny Maryland Transmission Company, LLC for no consideration.
On August 22, 2017 the two Kemptown properties, along with several other smaller properties in Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia were sold at public auction. F.C. Frederick, Inc. a non-profit soccer club based in Frederick Maryland submitted the winning bids on the Kemptown properties. Settlement on the transaction occurred in October 2017 at a price of $1.008 million.

'''Richard Adkerson''' is the current president, CEO and vice chairman of [[Freeport-McMoRan|Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc.]] with an established career in the mining sector. He has been in this role since December 2003. He is also known for his past role as chairman of the [[International Council on Mining and Metals]].<ref name=CEO>{{cite news|title=Profiles: Richard Adkerson |url=http://www.europeanceo.com/profiles/2008/06/richard-adkerson-freeportmcmoran/|publisher=EuropeanCEO.com|date=29 June 2008|accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref>
==Education== Adkerson graduated with highest honours from [[Mississippi State University]] with a bachelor's degree in accounting in 1970. He also completed an advanced management program at [[Harvard Business School]].<ref name=Bloom />
==Career== Adkerson started out as an accountant in the unpredictable oil and gas business throughout the 1970s before being offered his first role at Freeport in 1989. He was a partner and managing director at [[Arthur Andersen]] where he managed the company’s oil and gas industry division. Between 1976 and 1978, he was a professional accounting fellow with the [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name=CEO />
Adkerson was the past chairman of the [[International Council on Mining and Metals]] and is currently a member of the [[Council on Foreign Relations]], [[The Business Council]], and the [[Business Roundtable]]. He serves on the advisory council of the [[Kissinger Institute on China and the United States]] and as a member of the [[Clinton Global Initiative]].<ref name=FCX>{{cite news|title=Executive Management at Freeport|url=http://www.fcx.com/ir/bios.htm|publisher=FCX.com|accessdate=30 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219142103/http://www.fcx.com/ir/bios.htm|archivedate=19 February 2014|df=}}</ref>
He serves on the board of directors of the Arizona Commerce Authority, Greater Phoenix Leadership, and the [[Greater Phoenix Economic Council]]. He is vice chairman of the [[National World War II Museum]], and also serves on the board of visitors of the [[MD Anderson Cancer Center]] in [[Houston, Texas]]. Additionally, he is a member of the [[Mississippi State University]] Foundation’s board of directors.<ref name=Bloom>{{cite news|title=Executive profile: Richard Adkerson |url= http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=338733&ticker=FCX |publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=30 January 2014}}</ref>
It was revealed in November 2014 that Adkerson made $55 million in 2014, ranking him as the third highest paid US executive.<ref>{{cite news|title=Phoenix CEO made $55 million last year, the third-highest pay among US executives |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/blog/business/2014/05/phoenix-ceo-made-55-million-last-year-the-third.html?page=all|publisher=BizJournals|date=27 May 2014|accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref>
==Recognition== Adkerson received The American Institute of Mining, Metallurgical and Petroleum Engineers Charles F. Rand Memorial Award in 2011 and was named Executive of the Year by the W. P. Carey School of Business Dean’s Council at Arizona State University in 2011. He has been named The Best CEO in Metals and Mining by [[Institutional Investor (magazine)|Institutional Investor]] magazine for four years running and was named The Copper Man of the Year 2009 by The Copper Club.<ref name=FCX />
==Personal life== Adkerson lives in [[Phoenix, Arizona]] and also has a house in [[New Orleans]], which was subject to a well-publicised activist protest against Freeport’s mining activities in [[Papua, Indonesia]]. Adkerson has three sons.<ref name=CEO />

'''Robert Lucas Chance''' (8 October 1782 – 7 March 1865),<ref name=thepeeragewc>[http://www.thepeerage.com/p21406.htm#i214059 thePeerage.com - William Chance, father of the founders]</ref> was the fifth child and eldest son of William Chance (a partner in [[Nailsea Glassworks]]) and Sarah Lucas (daughter of John Robert Lucas). He was always known as '''Lucas Chance'''.
==Working life== He started work at his father's business in [[Birmingham]], at the age of 12, then started his own glass merchant business in London in 1815. This involved many trips to France where he formed alliances with French owners. In 1824 he purchased the British Crown Glass Company, following the death of the owner, Thomas Shutt, for £24,000, which is worth around £1 million in 2009.
He founded Chance Glass works, then formed a partnership with John Hartley in 1828. After experiencing financial difficulties in 1832, Lucas was then saved by his brother, William, who also became a partner. The partnership with Hartley's sons (who inherited the partnership on their father's death in 1833) was dissolved in 1836 and the business was then named [[Chance Brothers]] & Company.
In 1830, he became great friends with [[Georges Bontemps]], a leading director of a glassworks in France, who would later assist at Chance Brothers following his exile from France. Chance was instrumental in introducing the method of Sheet glass production for making flat glass for (primarily) windows. This would eventually dispose the previous working method of Crown glass. He was also one of the great exponents in removing the crippling excise duty and the [[Window Tax]]. Following these actions, the glass trade in England started to flourish.
In 1851, Chance Brothers supplied the glass to glaze the [[The Crystal Palace|Crystal Palace]], which was probably partly due to Chance's previous links with [[Joseph Paxton]], the architect, when supplying glass for the greenhouses at [[Chatsworth House]].
The two brothers were noted as being very philanthropic, founding a school (1845), a library and a church, all primarily for the workforce. Lucas Chance died in 1865.

revision.text:
[[File:Sally Fairfax.jpg|thumb|right|Sally Fairfax]]
'''Sally Cary Fairfax''' ({{circa}}1730 – 1811 in Bath, England) was the wife of [[George William Fairfax]] (1729–1787), a prominent member of the [[landed gentry]] of late [[colonial Virginia]]. As such, she was [[Mistress (form of address)|mistress]] of the [[Plantation economy|Virginia plantation]] and [[Estate (house)|estate]] of [[Belvoir (plantation)|Belvoir]]. She is well-remembered for being the woman [[George Washington]] was apparently in love with just before his marriage to [[Martha Washington|Martha Dandridge Custis]].<ref name="test">[http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/ah/2009/3/2009_3_42.shtml Thomas Fleming] "George Washington in Love," ''American Heritage'', Fall 2009.</ref>
==Biography==
===Family, early life and marriage=== Sally Cary, as she was born, came from one of [[Virginia]]'s oldest and wealthiest families. Her forefather, [[Miles Cary]] of [[Bristol]], [[England]], first came to America in the mid-17th century and established himself as a Virginian nobleman. [[Colonel Wilson Cary]], Sally's father and a member of the [[House of Burgesses]], inherited one of Virginia's largest fortunes and the family estate, [[Ceelys on the James]]. Little is known about his wife and Sally's mother, Sarah, on account of an 1826 fire that destroyed many of the family's records. Out of Colonel Cary's four daughters, the eldest Sally was the most sought-after and a grande belle in Virginian society. Although she had many suitors, [[George William Fairfax]] eventually won Sally's favor, and in records found by [[Wilson Miles Cary]], a writer and family historian, their marriage was announced in ''[[The Virginia Gazette]]'' in December 1748. After their marriage, Sally and George William moved into the [[Belvoir (plantation)|Belvoir]] estate that had been established in the early 1740s, by his father Col. [[William Fairfax]].
The [[Lord Fairfax of Cameron|Fairfax family]], as the Carys, was a living remnant of European feudalism and English aristocracy. Fairfax family members generally held the reins of social and political power in Virginia.
===Relationship with George Washington=== George William's sister, Anne Fairfax, married [[Lawrence Washington (1718-1752)|Lawrence Washington]] soon after George William's marriage to Sally. Lawrence's adolescent [[half-brother]], [[George Washington]], began visiting Belvoir frequently. Wishing to advance his brother's fortunes, Lawrence introduced George to George William. A friendship grew between the two men, who were close in age. Yet a relationship also blossomed between Sally Fairfax and George Washington. Sally had been well-educated under the Colonel's supervision, and as a young man with limited education and inexperienced in climbing the social ladder, Washington was impressed with this attractive, popular, and intelligent woman—arguably viewing her as the ideal of womanhood. She was a key inspiration for the future [[President of the United States|President]] to elevate himself to a higher social, cultural, and intellectual sphere, which is clear in the increasing level of refinement in his letters to her.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.virginialiving.com/virginiana/history/the-lady-of-belvoir/ |title=The Lady of Belvoir |last1=Darden |first1=Tyler |last2= |first2= |date=August 20, 2010 |website=''[[Virginia Living]]'' |publisher=Cape Fear Publishing|access-date=June 24, 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
While serving in the [[Forbes Expedition|Forbes campaign]] in September 1758, Washington wrote a particularly famous letter to Sally, telling her that "Tis true, I profess myself a Votary to Love…I feel the force of her amiable beauties in the recollection of a thousand tender passages that I wish to obliterate, till I am bid to revive them – but experience alas! Sadly reminds me how Impossible this is." In another letter, he makes an allusion to the literary characters [[Juba II|Juba]], prince of Numidia, who loves Cato's daughter [[Marcia (given name)|Marcia]], in the play ''[[Cato, a Tragedy|Cato]]'', by [[Joseph Addison]]. This ambiguity makes the question of the relationship's consummation frustrating to historians, and the answer is still unknown.
Despite any feelings he may have felt for Sally Fairfax, Washington married the wealthy [[Martha Dandridge Custis]], perhaps to heighten his social status, but their marriage appears to have been strong. Sally and George William were, in fact, the most frequent visitors to [[Mount Vernon (plantation)|Mount Vernon]], implying that any inkling the spouses had of previous indiscretions (or flirtation) was politely ignored.<ref>{{cite journal| author=Thomas Flexner| title=George Washington in Love| work=American Heritage| date=Fall 2009| page= 48}}</ref>
===Later years=== The happy foursome separated in 1773 when the Fairfaxes repaired to England to attend to family matters. Thereafter, George William's fortunes were crushed. As a [[Loyalist (American Revolution)|Loyalist]], he had every intention of returning to America after the [[United States Declaration of Independence|1776 insurrection]] was over, but the success of the [[American Revolution|Revolution]] prevented either of them from ever returning. He died in 1787 and Sally then lived alone in Bath until her death in 1811.
There were signs of regret on Sally's part in the end. She wrote to her sister-in-law in 1788: "I know now that the worthy man is to be preferred to the high-born who has not merit to recommend him…when we enquire into the family of these mighty men we find them the very lowest of people." Washington, too, confesses to Sally in a letter that she was the passion of his youth and that not all the glories of the Revolution, not even the splendors of the Presidency, had "been able to eradicate from my mind those happy moments, the happiest in my life, which I have enjoyed in your company."<ref>{{cite book|author=James Thomas Flexner|title=Washington: The Indispensable Man (paperback)|publisher=Back Bay Books (Little Brown and Company)|place=New York|year=1974|page= 364|ISBN=0-316-28605-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.trivia-library.com/a/president-george-washington-personal-life.htm|title=President George Washington: Personal Life|access-date=2018-11-10}}</ref>
== Bibliography == Note: All excerpts from correspondence have been taken from Wilson Miles Cary's ''Sally Cary: A Long Hidden Romance of Washington's Life.'' (See Bibliography)
* Wilson Miles Cary, ''Sally Cary: A Long Hidden Romance of Washington's Life'', New York: The DeVine Press, 1916. * Joseph J. Ellis, ''His Excellency George Washington'', New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 2004. * Nathaniel Wright Stevenson, "The Romantics and George Washington", In: ''[[The American Historical Review]]'', Vol. 39, No. 2 (Jan., 1934), p. 274-283. * Paul van Dyke, "Washington" In ''[[Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society]]'', Vol. 71, No. 4 (Apr., 1932), p. 191-205. * ''Martha Washington'', by Patricia Brady (2006).
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/21323135 Sally Fairfax at Find a grave]

{{Infobox rail |railroad_name = Spokane, Portland and Seattle Railway |logo_filename = Logo of the Spokane, Portland and Seattle Railway.png |logo_size = 150 |system_map = |map_caption = SP&S system map, late 1960s |map_size = 300 |marks = SPS |image = SP^S 801 Lv PDX July 1970cr - Flickr - drewj1946.jpg |image_size = |image_caption = [[EMD F3]] #801 departing [[Union Station (Portland, Oregon)|Union Station]] in Portland, Oregon, 1970 |locale = [[Oregon]]
[[Washington (state)|Washington]]| |start_year = 1905 |end_year = 1970 |predecessor_line = |successor_line = [[Burlington Northern Railroad]] |gauge = {{track gauge|ussg|allk=on}} |old_gauge = |electrification = |length = {{convert|922|mi|abbr=off}} |hq_city = [[Portland, Oregon]] |website = }} [[File:Steam locomotive in Vancouver, Washington -a.jpg|thumb|253px|Preserved SP&S "Northern" locomotive (2008)]] The '''Spokane, Portland & Seattle Railway''' ('''SP&S''') {{reporting mark|SPS}} was a [[United States]]-based [[railroad]] incorporated in 1905. It was a joint venture by the [[Great Northern Railway (U.S.)|Great Northern Railway]] and the [[Northern Pacific Railway]] to build a railroad along the north bank of the [[Columbia River]]. Remnants of the line are currently operated by [[BNSF Railway]] and the [[Portland and Western Railroad]]. ==History== The railroad was chartered in 1905 by [[James J. Hill]] to connect the two transcontinental railroads owned by him, the [[Northern Pacific Railway|Northern Pacific]] (NP) and [[Great Northern Railway (U.S.)|Great Northern]] (GN), to [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Oregon]] from [[Spokane, Washington|Spokane]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]],''The history of bnsf: A legacy for the 21st century''. Railway: The employee magazine of burlington northern sante fe corporation, 27. Retrieved from http://www.bnsf.com/about-bnsf/our-railroad/company-history/pdf/hist_overview.pdf to gain a portion of the lumber trade in Oregon, a business then dominated by [[E.H. Harriman]]'s [[Union Pacific Railroad|Union Pacific]] and [[Southern Pacific Transportation Company|Southern Pacific]] railroads. Construction began in 1906"Greatest Year for Railroad Construction: Building in Territory Tributary to Portland During 1906 Breaks All Records—City Now Strategic Point in Struggle of Giants". (January 1, 1907). ''[[The Oregonian|The Morning Oregonian]]" (Portland), section 2, p. 20. under the name Portland & Seattle Railway,{{cite web|url=http://www.american-rails.com/spokane-portland-and-seattle.html|title=The Spokane, Portland and Seattle Railway, ''The Northwest’s Own Railway''|publisher=American-Rails.com|accessdate=25 April 2010}} proceeding eastward from [[Vancouver, Washington]].{{Schafer-Classic-Railroads-3}} 1906 also saw the start of construction of the line between Vancouver and Portland, including work on three major new bridges, [[Burlington Northern Railroad Bridge 9.6|crossing the Columbia River]], the [[Oregon Slough Railroad Bridge|Oregon Slough]] and the [[Burlington Northern Railroad Bridge 5.1|Willamette River]]. The northernmost of these was the first bridge of any kind to be built across the lower [[Columbia River]]."Finish Bridge Over Columbia; Steel Structure of the Spokane, Portland & Seattle Railroad [sic] Completed—Last Bolt In Yesterday". (June 26, 1908). ''[[The Oregonian|The Morning Oregonian]]'' (Portland), p. 11. Despite legal challenges from Harriman, within a year the line had been built as far as [[Pasco, Washington]] along the Columbia River, where it connected with NP. The first section to open was from Pasco west to Cliffs (near [[Maryhill, Washington|Maryhill]]), a length of {{convert|112|mi|km}}, on December 15, 1907."History of North Bank Road". (November 6, 1908). ''The Morning Oregonian'', p. 12. Operation was extended west to [[Lyle, Washington|Lyle]], {{convert|33|mi|km}} further west, on January 15, 1908, as construction continued on the {{convert|221|mi|km|adj=on}} section from Pasco to Vancouver. [[File:Ocean Shore Limited Spokane Portland and Seattle Railroad.JPG|thumb|200px|SP&S also operated the ''Ocean Shore Limited'', shown here at [[Seaside, Oregon]]]] In January 1908 "Spokane" was added to the railroad's name, making it the '''Spokane, Portland & Seattle Railway'''."Important Articles Filed: North Bank Changes Name [from Portland & Seattle Railway Company to Spokane, Portland & Seattle Railway Company], Increases Capital and Will Extend". (January 30, 1908). ''[[The Oregonian|The Morning Oregonian]]'' (Portland), p. 11. SP&S freight and passenger service (from Pasco) to Portland was inaugurated in November 1908."First Train on Hill Road: Regular Passenger Service Inaugurated From Local Terminus". (November 18, 1908). ''The Morning Oregonian'', p. 11. By 1909 the railroad had completed construction of its line up to Spokane along the [[Snake River]]. In 1910 SP&S gained control of the [[Oregon Electric Railway|Oregon Electric]] interurban railway, which the Great Northern had acquired two years before. Under the control of the SP&S the railroad was extended southward to [[Eugene, Oregon]] by 1912. SP&S also operated a second subsidiary railroad in western Oregon, the [[Oregon Traction Company]], which owned a route to [[Seaside, Oregon]]. [[File:Spokane, Portland & Seattle Railway.jpg|thumb|Oregon Traction Company route to Seaside (Holiday) in 1930]] [[File:Oregon Trunk Line.jpg|thumb|Oregon Trunk RR route in 1931]] A third route on which the SP&S operated extended southward from [[Wishram, Washington]] to [[Bend, Oregon]] was the Oregon Trunk Railroad. Edward Harriman's Oregon & Washington Railway & Navigation Company also was building a railroad south from the Columbia River to Bend resulting in a railroad war in which each railroad attempted to sabotage the other. In the end, the railroad opened using mostly the track of the Oregon Trunk, with a short portion of the Oregon & Washington Railway & Navigation Company track, and both railroads used the route (an arrangement that still exists with BNSF owning the majority of the line and UP having trackage rights). During [[World War II]] the SP&S carried war materials to the [[Pacific Ocean theatre of World War II|Pacific Theatre]]; new industries located along the Columbia River, taking advantage of cheap electricity from [[hydroelectric]] dams on the river. New industries served by the SP&S included aluminum plants, sawmills, chemical factories and grain elevators.{{cite web|url=http://www.spshs.org/history.html|title=HISTORY|publisher=SP&S Railway Historical Society Railroad|year=2004|accessdate=27 April 2010}} In 1954 an SP&S train derailed after hitting a rockslide on the route to Bend, Oregon. Part of the train landed in the [[Deschutes River (Oregon)|Deschutes River]], including a boxcar, which landed in a rapid that was later named "[[Boxcar Rapids]]" after the incident, which killed all crew members.{{cite web|url=http://www.wasco-history.r9esd.k12.or.us/comm/maupin/oldpics/railroad/boxcar.html|title=S.P.&S. Engine wrecked near Maupin|publisher=Wasco County History Site|accessdate=27 April 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224203937/http://www.wasco-history.r9esd.k12.or.us/comm/maupin/oldpics/railroad/boxcar.html|archivedate=24 February 2012|df=}} == Passenger trains == [[File:Spokane Portland and Seattle Railroad North Bank dining car.JPG|thumb|200px|Dining car of the ''North Bank Limited'']] The SP&S's passenger operations mostly involved hosting connections with parents' trains, such as the ''[[Empire Builder]]'' and ''[[North Coast Limited]]'', which were combined to form the Streamliner (#1/#2). ''[[Oriental Limited]]'', ''[[Mainstreeter]]'', and ''[[Western Star (train)|Western Star]]'' connected with (#3/#4).{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} However, some of these SP&S trains were named. The ''Inland Empire Express'' (daytime) and ''North Bank Limited'' (overnight) provided daily, through service between Portland ([[Union Station (Portland, Oregon)|Union Station]]) and Spokane."Mountain, River and Canyon Scenery to Spokane" (SP&S advertisement). (February 28, 1922). ''[[The Oregonian|The Morning Oregonian]]'' (Portland), p. 7. The ''Columbia River Express'' (#5/#6) operated between Portland and Pasco, connecting at Pasco with Northern Pacific #5/#6 for service to/from Spokane.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} == See also == * [[North Bank Depot Buildings]] – Portland terminal for SP&S service, 1908–1920s * [[Spokane, Portland and Seattle 700]] * [[Spokane, Portland and Seattle Locomotive Roster]] * [[Spokane, Portland and Seattle Railroad Warehouse]] ==References== {{Portal|Railways}} {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book| last = Gaertner | first = John T.| title = North Bank Road | year = 1990 |publisher=[[Washington State University Press]]| isbn=978-0-87422-070-4}} * {{cite journal |title=Spokane, Portland and Seattle Railroad Company |author= L. C. Gilman |journal= Washington Historical Quarterly |volume=14 |year= 1923 |jstor= 40474682 }} * {{cite book | last = Grande | first = Walt | title = The Northwest's Own Railway, Spokane Portland & Seattle Railway and its Subsidiaries | year = 1997 }} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.spshs.org/ Spokane Portland and Seattle Railway Historical Society] {{Former Class I}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Spokane Portland Seattle Railway}} [[Category:Spokane, Portland and Seattle Railway| ]] [[Category:Predecessors of the Burlington Northern Railroad]] [[Category:Former Class I railroads in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct Washington (state) railroads]] [[Category:Defunct Oregon railroads]] [[Category:Railway companies established in 1908]] [[Category:Railway companies disestablished in 1979]] [[Category:Joint ventures]] [[Category:1908 establishments in the United States]]

The company is listed on the first section of the [[Tokyo Stock Exchange]] and is a constituent of the on the [[Nikkei 225]]{{cite web |url=http://indexes.nikkei.co.jp/en/nkave/index/component?idx=nk225#07 |title=Components:Nikkei Stock Average |publisher=[[Nikkei Inc.]] |accessdate=February 7, 2014}} [[stock index]]. It's a member of the [[Sumitomo]] group and was founded in 1913 as a fertilizer manufacturing plant. ==Company Milestones== *1913: The House of Sumitomo establishes a fertilizer plant in Ehime to produce fertilizers from sulfur dioxide recovered from copper smelting emissions. *1915: Operations commence at the plant. *1925: Sumitomo Fertilizer Manufacturing Co., Ltd. is incorporated with operations at what is now the Ehime Works. *1934: Sumitomo Fertilizer Manufacturing changes its name to Sumitomo Chemical Co., Ltd. *1944: Sumitomo Chemical acquires Japan Dyestuff Manufacturing Company, starting a fine chemical business at the Osaka Works and the Oita Works. *1949: Sumitomo Chemical takes over the aluminum business of Sumitomo Aluminium Smelting Co., starting the integrated production of aluminum from alumina. *1958: Sumitomo Chemical starts petrochemical operations at its Ehime Works. *1965: The Takatsuki Research Laboratory is completed, serving as the Company's central laboratory. Sumitomo Chiba Chemical Co., Ltd. is established and begins petrochemical operations at the Chiba Works. *1971: The Takarazuka Research Center is established to reinforce research and development activities on pharmaceuticals and agricultural chemicals. *1976: The aluminum operation is transferred to the newly formed Sumitomo Aluminium Smelting Co., Ltd. *1978: The Misawa Works is opened to expand production of pyrethroid household insecticides. *1982: P.T. Indonesia Asahan Aluminium, a Japan-Indonesia economic cooperation project, of which Sumitomo Chemical is a member, begins aluminum smelting operations. *1983: Sumitomo Chemical integrates the petrochemical operations at its Ehime Works into its Chiba Works. *1984: Sumitomo Pharmaceuticals Co., Ltd. established by consolidating the pharmaceutical operations of Sumitomo Chemical and pharmaceuticals division of [[Inabata & Co., Ltd.]] The Petrochemical Complex in Singapore, a Japan-Singapore economic cooperation project, in which Sumitomo Chemical is a leading participant, begins operations. *1988: The Biochemistry & Toxicology Laboratory, subsequently renamed the Environmental Health Science Laboratory, is established in the Osaka Works. *1989: The Tsukuba Research Laboratory is established to reinforce research and development on new materials. *1997: Petrochemical Corporation of Singapore (Pte.) Ltd., an affiliate in Singapore, commences operation of a new ethylene cracker in April under its second phase expansion project, bringing the total ethylene capacity to one million tons per year, and making it the largest petrochemical complex in East Asia consisting of various downstream units. *1998: Facilities in Singapore for the manufacture of acrylic acid and its derivatives, including methyl methacrylate resins, under a project which Sumitomo Chemical was promoting with other Japanese companies, are completed in October. *2000: Sumitomo Chemical establishes Genomic Science Laboratories, operated jointly with Sumitomo Pharmaceuticals. *2001: Sumitomo Chemical acquires household insecticide business of Aventis Crop Science. Sumitomo Chemical establishes the IT-related Chemicals Sector as a new business sector. *2002: Sumitomo Chemical Takeda Agro Co., Ltd., a joint venture between Sumitomo Chemical and Takeda Chemical Industries, Ltd., succeeds Takeda Chemical’s agrochemical business and commences operation. *2003: Sumitomo Chemical's subsidiary Dongwoo STI Co., Ltd. commences operation of a large-scale TFT-LCD color filters production plant in Korea. Sumitomo Chemical opens LCD Polarizing film plant in Korea. *2004: Sumitomo Chemical opens LCD Polarizing film plant in Taiwan. *2005: Sumitomo Chemical establishes equally owned joint venture Rabigh Refining and Petrochemical Company (Petro Rabigh) together with Saudi Aramco. Sumitomo Pharmaceuticals and Dainippon Pharmaceuticals merged to form [[Dainippon Sumitomo Pharma]]. *2007: Sumitomo Chemical acquired the UK company [[Cambridge Display Technology]], a pioneer in the development of polymer organic LEDs and related devices, and made it a wholly owned subsidiary.{{cite web |last1=LaPedus |first1=Mark |title=Sumitomo buys Cambridge Display Technology |url=https://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1166722 |website=EE Times |publisher=AspenCore |accessdate=29 September 2018}} *2009: Petro Rabigh's integrated refining and petrochemical complex starts operations. *2010: Sumitomo Chemical acquires Indian agrochemical manufacturer New Chemi Industries Ltd with an eye to expand its crop-protection product business in India’s growing market. *2016: Japan's Sumitomo Chemicals is acquires promoters’ stake in Excel Crop Care, a Mumbai-based agro-chemical manufacturer. *2017: Sumitomo Chemical acquires 82.9 % of Botanical Resources Australia Group.{{cite web |title=Acquisition of Botanical Resources Australia Group, a major supplier of pyrethrum-derived insecticidal compounds |url=https://www.sumitomo-chem.co.jp/english/newsreleases/docs/20171122e.pdf |website=sumitomo-chem.co.jp |publisher=Sumitomo Chemical |accessdate=29 September 2018}}{{cite web |last1=Rana |first1=Sanjiv |title=Sumitomo acquires Botanical Resources Australia |url=https://agrow.agribusinessintelligence.informa.com/AG028733/Sumitomo-acquires-Botanical-Resources-Australia |website=Agribusiness intelligence |publisher=Informa PLC |accessdate=29 September 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Japan|Chemistry|Engineering|Companies}} *{{Official {{Infobox book | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | image = The One Minute Manager.jpg | border = yes | caption = | author = {{ubl|[[Ken Blanchard]]|[[Spencer Johnson (writer)|Spencer Johnson]]}} | country = United States | language = English | publisher = [[William Morrow & Co]] | series = | genre = Business / Self-help / Motivational | pages = 112 | release_date = 1982 | isbn = 978-0-00-636753-6 }}
'''''The One Minute Manager''''' is a very short book by [[Ken Blanchard]] and [[Spencer Johnson (writer)|Spencer Johnson]]. The brief volume tells a story, recounting three techniques of an effective [[management|manager]]: one-minute [[goal setting|goals]], one-minute [[praise|praisings]] and one-minute [[reprimand]]s. Each of these takes only a minute but is purportedly of lasting benefit.<ref>[http://www.bruinleaders.ucla.edu/documents/BLP_samplebookreview.pdf Book review] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110101235854/http://www.bruinleaders.ucla.edu/documents/BLP_samplebookreview.pdf |date=2011-01-01 }} by Eric Spamer, Bruin Leaders Project, [[UCLA]]</ref>
==Sequels== It was followed by a sequel, ''Leadership and the One Minute Manager'', by Ken Blanchard, Patricia Zigarmi and Drea Zigarmi, which laid out Blanchard's Situational Leadership II concept.<ref>Kenneth H. Blanchard, Patricia Zigarmi, and Drea Zigarmi. ''[http://www.kenblanchard.com/Store/Books_Audios/Leadership_Starters/Leadership_and_the_One_Minute_Manager/ Leadership and the One Minute Manager: Increasing Effectiveness through Situational Leadership]''. New York: Morrow, 1985.</ref>
==Criticisms==
The concept has been called a [[management fad]], and derivative of [[management by objectives]], itself derived from the business planning literature.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Miller | first1 = Danny | last2 = Hartwick | first2 = Jon | title = Spotting Management Fads | journal = [[Harvard Business Review]] | volume = | issue = | page = 27 | publisher = | location = | date = October 2002 | url = http://www.hear-see-do.com/AM/projects/spotting%20management%20fads.pdf | jstor = | issn = | doi = | accessdate = 2011-07-23 }} </ref> One critic called it "the executive equivalent of paper-training your dog."<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Jackson | first = S. | date = January 20, 1986 | title = Management lingo: how to read between the lines | journal = Business Week | page = 58 }}, in {{Cite journal | last = Graeff | first = Claude L. | title = Evolution of Situational Leadership Theory: A Critical Review | journal = Leadership Quarterly | volume = 8 | issue = 2 | pages = 156–157 | publisher = JAI Press, Inc. | location = | year = 1997 | url = http://www.ea.ufrgs.br/pos/home/turmas/esp2006/gp2006/Download/ArquivoProfessor/evolucao%20da%20teoria%20situacional.pdf | jstor = | issn = | accessdate = 2011-07-23 }} </ref>
==Controversies== While the book was becoming a best-seller, the ''Wall Street Journal'' ran an article exposing it as a heavily plagiarized document.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Ober | first = Scot | title = Business Communication | publisher = Houghton Mifflin College Division | edition = 5 | year = 2002 | page = 435 | url = https://books.google.com/books?ei=XHEqTsrLEo2CmQWb54yeDA&ct=result&id=IUfp7H3PKa4C&dq=one-minute-manager+plagiarism&q=one-minute-manager#search_anchor | isbn = 0618343296 }} </ref> The article asserted that almost half of the book was lifted directly from an article previously published by University of Massachusetts at Amherst professor Arthur Elliott Carlisle.<ref>[http://www.jonentine.com/reviews/sf_chronicle.htm The Liars' Club] by Jon Entine, ''San Francisco Chronicle''</ref> Blanchard and Johnson offered conflicting stories on their reasons for not citing the original author, including an insistence, later abandoned, that one of them helped Carlisle write the original article.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Entine | first = Jon | title = Uh-oh: The feckless defense of fabulists | newspaper = [[Chicago Tribune]] | location = Chicago, IL | page = 19 | date = Jun 27, 2001 | url = http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2001-06-27/news/0106270394_1_common-thread-spencer-johnson-offered | accessdate = 2018-07-28 }} </ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://kenblanchard.com/ kenblanchard.com] - homepage of ''The Ken Blanchard Companies'' *[http://www.kenblanchard.com/Issues_Organizational_Development/Effective_Leadership_Solutions/One_to_One_Talent_Management/Management_Situational_Leadership_Training/ Blanchard's Situational Leadership II Model]

{{Infobox person | image = Oelrichs_Vanderbilts.jpg | caption = ''Oelrichs (seated) with her son standing on left, c. 1910'' | birth_name = Theresa Alice Fair | birth_date = June 30, 1871 | birth_place = [[Virginia City]], [[Nevada]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1926|11|22|1871|6|30}} | death_place = [[Newport, Rhode Island|Newport]], [[Rhode Island]], U.S. | spouse = {{marriage|[[Hermann Oelrichs]]
|June 3, 1890|September 1, 1906|reason=his death}} | children = Hermann Oelrichs, Jr. | parents = [[James Graham Fair]]
Theresa Rooney | relatives = [[Virginia Fair Vanderbilt]] (sister) }} '''Theresa Alice "Tessie" Fair''' (June 30, 1871 – November 22, 1926) was an American [[socialite]]. She went from being the daughter of a hard-scrabble California miner to become heiress to a fortune in [[Comstock Lode]] gold and silver, the wife of steamship magnate [[Hermann Oelrichs]], mistress of the [[Rosecliff]] estate in [[Newport, Rhode Island]], and a member of the elite "Triumvirate" of American society. == Early life == Tessie was born on June 30, 1871 in [[Virginia City]], [[Nevada]]. Her father, [[James Graham Fair]], was born in [[Clogher]], [[County Tyrone]], and immigrated to the United States from [[Belfast, Ireland]] in 1843 at age twelve. He worked the California mines until 1860, when he moved to Nevada to work the newly-discovered traces there. He met Theresa Rooney, an innkeeper's daughter, and they wed in 1861. Tessie grew up in mining camps as her father prospected for gold and was the eldest of four children born to her parents, including [[Virginia Fair Vanderbilt|Virginia]] (nicknamed "Birdie"), Charles and James, Jr. In 1873, her father and three partners,{{refn|group=lower-alpha|The four partners were [[John William Mackay]], [[James Graham Fair]], [[James C. Flood]] and [[William S. O'Brien]], who were collectively known as the [[Bonanza Kings]].{{cite news |title=THE MINING ARISTOCRACY. SOCIAL STANDING OF SAN FRANCISCO'S BONANZA KINGS. THE ANCIENT FEUDS OF THE MAGNATES OF THE MINES—FLOOD AND O'BRIEN, FAIR AND MACKEY, MORROW AND BALDWIN IGNORED IN SOCIETY—RALSTON'S RUIN—THE EXPLOITS AND CHARITIES OF "KNIGHTLY JIM" KEENE. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1876/12/15/80355890.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 15, 1876}}}} discovered the "[[Comstock Lode|Big Bonanza]]" in [[Virginia City]], Nevada, which became the largest single deposit of gold and silver ever found. More than $100 million dollars worth of gold (over $2.5 billion in today's currency) was extracted from that mine before it was exhausted in 1898. Fair used his share to expand into railroads and real estate, generating a fortune of $50 million. Money led to a dissolute life of affairs and drinking for him, and in 1883 his wife filed for divorce, getting custody of Tessie and Virginia. ==Personal life== [[File:American homes and gardens (1905) (17531068663).jpg|thumb|right|Rosecliff's dining room in the Louis XVI style, 1905.]][[File:American homes and gardens (1905) (18125155786).jpg|thumb|right|Rosecliff's staircase, 1905.]][[File:American homes and gardens (1905) (18148107132).jpg|thumb|right|Rosecliff's rear steps.]] In 1889, in Newport, Tessie met steamship tycoon [[Hermann Oelrichs]], whom she wed the following year on June 3, 1890.{{cite news |title=HERMANN OELRICHS WEDS. HE GOES ACROSS THE CONTINENT AND SECURES A CALIFORNIA BRIDE. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1890/06/04/103246388.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 4, 1890}} The lavish wedding was held in San Francisco. James Fair's gift to his daughter was one million dollars, but even so he was not invited to the wedding. Now a wealthy heiress, Tessie moved east permanently to join the social circles of New York, Newport and Europe. Tessie later gave birth to her only child: * Hermann Oelrichs, Jr. (1891–1948),{{cite news |title=HERMANN OELRICHS DIES AT HOME HERE; Society Leader Who Had Been in Diplomatic Service Was Son of Shipping Executive |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1948/08/06/88121948.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 6, 1948 |language=en}} who married Dorothy Haydel (1893–1961) in 1925.{{cite news |title=HERMANN OELRICHS WEDS MISS HAYDEL; New Yorker Married to St. Louis Girl in Biarritz, France, on Last Tuesday. THEIR TROTH TOLD IN MAY Wedding Was First Set for June 29 -- Bridegroom !s Nephew of Mrs. W. K. Vanderbilt. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1925/09/16/100019244.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 16, 1925 |language=en}} After his death, she married Prince Ferdinand von Liechtenstein (1901–1981) in 1950.{{cite news |title=LIECHTENSTEIN PRINCE WEDS MRS. OELRICHS |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1950/08/22/95802565.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=August 22, 1950 |language=en}} She publicly acted as a devoted and happy wife, but privately, she and Hermann were estranged. When news reached her that he survived the massive [[1906 San Francisco earthquake|San Francisco earthquake]] of 1906, she hoped for a reconciliation.{{cite news |title=NO WORD FROM FRIENDS. Anxiety for Many New Yorkers Who Were in San Francisco. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1906/04/21/101775327.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 21, 1906}}{{cite news |title=MR. OELRICHS'S STORY. He Did Police Duty in the Streets of San Francisco. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1906/04/28/101839277.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 28, 1906}} Hermann returned east, so she prepared a lavish supper for them together. When he did not attend, she was enraged. Unreconciled, Hermann later died of a heart attack.{{cite news |title=HERMANN OELRICHS DIES ON A LINER AT SEA {{!}} His Work in the San Francisco Earthquake Hastened His End. {{!}} NEWS COMES BY WIRELESS {{!}} He Died on Saturday on the Big Kaiser — No Details Yet — Widow Hurries from Newport. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1906/09/04/101378162.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 4, 1906}}{{cite news |title=MR. OELRICHS'S BODY BROUGHT TO HIS WIDOW She and Mrs. Vanderbilt Meet It at the Pier. CAUSE OF DEATH MADE KNOWN Bright's Disease Killed the Famous Amateur Athlete and Society Leader — Warned of His Fate. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1906/09/05/101378496.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 5, 1906}}{{cite news |title=HERMANN OELRICHS BURIED. His Funeral Attended by Many Friends and Former Business Associates. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1906/09/06/102422102.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 6, 1906}} He left his full estate to his brother [[Charles May Oelrichs]], thinking that Tessie would be content with her own fortune,{{cite news |title=MRS. OELRICHS LEFT OUT OF HER HUSBAND'S WILL Testator Says She Has a Fortune of Her Own. SON GETS PERSONAL EFFECTS The Fortune, Whose Value Is Unknown, Is Divided Among Relatives — $300,000 to Brother. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1906/09/11/101797465.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 11, 1906}} but Tessie contested the will.{{cite news |title=WIDOW MAY CONTEST MR. OELRICHS'S WILL She Now Wants to Administer Her Brother's Estate. TWO WILLS SAID TO EXIST One Executed in 1902 Gave Mrs. Oelrichs the Estate Now Left to Oelrichs's Brother. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1906/09/12/101831265.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 12, 1906}}{{cite news |title=OELRICHS WILL FIGHT BEGUN BY THE WIDOW Refusing a Compromise, She Objects to Probate Here. CALIFORNIA LAWS GOVERN Her Husband Being a Citizen of That State, She Says, Under the Law Half the Estate Is Hers. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1906/10/25/120282733.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 25, 1906}} Eventually, they settled the dispute and she received half of the estate.{{cite news |title=OELRICHS WILL FIGHT ENDED BY COMPROMISE The Widow to Get $100,000 in Bonds and Son a $50,000 Ranch. SHE ABANDONS ALL CLAIMS Settlement Also in Accounting of Trusteeship of Fair Estate by Hermann Oelrichs. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1906/11/25/101717344.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 25, 1906}}Gavan, Terrence. ''The Barons of Newport: A Guide to the Gilded Age''. Newport: Pineapple Publications, 1998. {{ISBN|0-929249-06-2}} Oelrichs died at Newport on November 22, 1926.{{cite news |title=MRS. H. OELRICHS, SOCIAL LEADER; With Sister, Mrs. William K, Vanderbilt Jr., Inherited J. G. Fair's Fortune. {{!}} ENTERTAINED IN SPLENDOR {{!}} One of Three Women Who Succeeded Mrs. William Astor, the Arbiter of Society. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1926/11/23/98408608.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 23, 1926 |language=en}} After a funeral in the "beautiful blue and gold tapestry room" at Rosecliff, which was attended by Charles M. Oelrichs and his wife among others, she was buried at [[Woodlawn Cemetery (Bronx)|Woodlawn Cemetery]], [[The Bronx]], New York City.{{cite news |title=HOLD FINAL RITES FOR MRS. OELRICHS; Only Relatives and Intimate Friends at Funeral of the Former Society Leader. {{!}} BURIAL IN THIS CITY TODAY {{!}} Floral Blanket Ordered From Paris by Sister, Mrs. W. K. Vanderbilt 2d, Covers Coffin. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1926/11/24/98409225.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 24, 1926 |language=en}}{{refn|group=lower-alpha|Her sister, [[Virginia Fair Vanderbilt]], was buried beside her at Woodlawn after her death in 1935.}} Her son inherited the vast majority of her estate with the provision that should he die without issue, her sister Virginia would be the residuary legatee.{{cite news |title=SON GETS OELRICHS ESTATE; Mrs. Theresa Oelrichs Also Left Trust Fund for Her Nurse |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1926/12/14/98528190.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 14, 1926 |language=en}} Her son later sold her stately home in 1941,{{cite news |title=OELRICHS ESTATE SOLD; Deed Names Abraham Leighter as Purchaser of Newport House |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1941/02/25/85240091.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 25, 1941 |language=en}}{{cite news |title=OELRICHS VILLA SOLD FOR $21,000; Mother Buys Former Newport Showplace as a Gift for Gertrude Niesen, Actress |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1941/07/17/87643450.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 17, 1941 |language=en}} and today, [[Rosecliff]] stands open to the public.{{cite news |last1=Columbia |first1=David Patrick |title=The Adventures of Tessie |url=http://www.newyorksocialdiary.com/social-history/2007/the-adventures-of-tessie |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[New York Social Diary]] |date=30 August 2007 |language=en}} ===Society life=== Tessie's social peers, [[Alva Vanderbilt]] and [[Grace Vanderbilt]], already had expensive mansions in Newport, which were called "summer cottages" by the elite of the day. Tessie set her sights on being mistress of her own grand estate, so she commissioned architect [[Stanford White]] to renovate their recently purchased [[Rosecliff]] on [[Bellevue Avenue]]. Begun in 1899, and purchased from the estate of [[George Bancroft]], Rosecliff was modeled after the [[Grand Trianon]] at [[Subsidiary structures of the Palace of Versailles|Versailles]], and was completed in 1902 with a final cost of $2.5 million.{{cite web |title=Rosecliff {{!}} Newport Mansions |url=http://www.newportmansions.org/explore/rosecliff |website=www.newportmansions.org |publisher=[[Preservation Society of Newport]] |accessdate=10 September 2018 |language=en}} In 1899, Tessie orchestrated a coup for the family by marrying her younger sister Birdie off to [[William K. Vanderbilt II]],{{cite news |title=MRS. VANDERBILT DIES IN HOME HERE {{!}} Former Wife of W. K. 2d, Long Social Leader in New York, Had Been III Nine Weeks {{!}} HAD NOTED RACING STABLE {{!}} Owner of Sarazen Was Heir to $5,000,000 Left by Father, Senator James G. Fair. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1935/07/08/94628960.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 8, 1935 |language=en}} son of Alva and [[William K. Vanderbilt]] and brother of [[Consuelo Vanderbilt]], [[Duke of Marlborough (title)|Duchess of Marlborough]], in a wedding that was extensively covered in the society pages.{{cite news |title=VANDERBILT-FAIR WEDDING. {{!}} MISS FAIR'S BRIDAL GIFTS {{!}} Shown Yesterday to Friends--To be on View to Guests To-day. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1899/04/02/100437859.pdf |accessdate=10 September 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 2, 1899}} In New York, they lived at 1 East 57th Street in "the big house at the northeast corner of [[Fifth Avenue]] and [[57th Street (Manhattan)|Fifth-seventh Street]]," which was later occupied by the [[New York Trust Company]]. Oelrichs then lived at 1 [[72nd Street (Manhattan)|East 72nd Street]]. '''Trevor James Flugge''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|f|l|uː|g|i}} {{respell|FLOO|ghee}}; born 1 February 1947) is an [[Australia]]n farmer and businessman. He is best known as a former official of the [[Australian Wheat Board]] (AWB).<ref>[http://www.australianwoolgrowers.com.au/media_links.html Australian Wool Growers Association] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070206002825/http://www.australianwoolgrowers.com.au/media_links.html |date=6 February 2007 }} (accessed:13-03-2007)</ref> He joined the board in 1984, was chair of AWB in 1995-2002, and was present at meetings in [[Iraq]] which were linked to the [[Oil-for-Food Programme#Oil for wheat|Oil-for-Food scandal]], and an [[Paul Volcker Committee|inquiry by the United Nations]].
==Background== Flugge was educated at [[Aquinas College, Perth]],<ref>[http://owca.org.au/june2004.pdf ''OWCA'', June 2004]</ref> and became a farmer in the [[Katanning, Western Australia|Katanning]] area.
In 1987, he was an unsuccessful [[National Party of Australia|National Party]] candidate for the seat of [[Division of O'Connor|O'Connor]] (against [[Wilson Tuckey]]) at the [[Australian federal election, 1987|Australian election]] that year.
Flugge has also served as chair of the Australian Wheat Growers Association, and as a board member of the major diversified company [[Wesfarmers]]
==Oil-for-Food scandal & the Cole Inquiry== Trevor Flugge was chair of AWB until March 2002, when he was voted off the board by A-class shareholders (wheat growers). He was appointed a consultant to AWB after the vote and travelled to [[Baghdad]] later that year, with AWB chairman [[Andrew Lindberg]], to rescue an AWB wheat export deal with [[Saddam Hussein]]'s regime.
There were later accusations that AWB had paid [[bribe]]s to secure the export contract. AWB officials agreed to pay [[US dollar|$]]2 million to the Iraqi regime, which would then allow wheat exports to resume. This payment was made by inflating the price of wheat contracts administered by the [[United Nations]] [[Oil-for-Food Program]].<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2006/02/02/1138836372830.html The Age - The Odd Stray Shot] (accessed:13-03-2007)</ref>
Following the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|2003 invasion]] and overthrow of the Hussein regime, Flugge was made a senior adviser to the Iraqi agriculture department.<ref>[http://www.dfat.gov.au/media/transcripts/2003/030422_flugge_iraq.html Transcript - Alexander Downer Interview] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070218154214/http://www.dfat.gov.au/media/transcripts/2003/030422_flugge_iraq.html |date=18 February 2007 }} (accessed:13-03-2007)</ref>
After the bribery became public in 2005, Flugge denied to the UN's [[Paul Volcker Committee|Volker inquiry]] that he knew about AWB's payments to the Hussein regime. Flugge was also called before an Australian government investigation in 2005, the [[Cole inquiry]]. When giving evidence to the latter inquiry, Flugge frequently claimed to have no knowledge of matters discussed at meetings he attended, due to hearing loss.

'''Walter Butler''' is a French/American [[businessman]]. He is the founder of [[Butler Capital Partners]], an investment and private equity firm.
== Early Life and Education == Walter Butler was born in Brazil<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/06/business/worldbusiness/a-venture-capitalist-is-shaking-up-france.html|title=A venture capitalist is shaking up France|last=Tagliabue|first=John|access-date=2018-08-14|language=en}}</ref> to a Brazilian mother and an American father.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.latribune.fr/entreprises-finance/banques-finance/industrie-financiere/20130107trib000741033/qui-est-butler-capital-partners-le-discret-proprietaire-de-virgin-megastore.html|title=Qui est Butler Capital Partners, le discret propriétaire de Virgin Megastore?|work=La Tribune|access-date=2018-08-14|language=fr-FR}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.challenges.fr/finance-et-marche/sncm-flo-psg-virgin-walter-butler-le-franc-tireur-du-sauvetage-d-entreprise_580594|title=SNCM, Flo, PSG, Virgin... Walter Butler, le franc-tireur du sauvetage d’entreprise|work=Challenges|access-date=2018-08-14|language=fr}}</ref> He moved from Brazil to France when he was a child following his parents' divorce.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/economie/article/2005/09/27/walter-butler-enarque-et-proche-de-dominique-de-villepin_693366_3234.html|title=Walter Butler, énarque et proche de Dominique de Villepin|work=Le Monde.fr|access-date=2018-09-12|language=fr-FR}}</ref>
Butler attended [[Institut d'études politiques de Bordeaux|Instituts d'études politiques de Bordeaux]] where he received a [[Master of Laws|Master of Law]] degree. He later attended [[École nationale d'administration|ÉNA]], an elite school for high-level civil servants, where he received a degree in 1980.<ref name=":3" />
He is a United States citizen.<ref name=":0" />
== Career == After completing studies at the [[École nationale d'administration|ÉNA]], Walter Butler served from 1983 to 1986 as an Inspector of Finances at the [[Minister of Finances (France)|French Ministry of Finances]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> From 1986 to 1988,{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} he was an advisor to the [[Ministry of Culture and Communications (Quebec)|Minister of Culture and Communication]] [[François Léotard]].<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2012/11/03/inspection-generale-des-finances-destins-d-une-elite-d-etat_1785169_823448.html|title=Inspection générale des finances : destins d'une élite d'Etat|work=Le Monde.fr|access-date=2018-08-16|language=fr-FR}}</ref> In this position, he played a key role in the privatization of French television channel [[TF1]], working alongside [[Jean-Marie Messier]].<ref name=":3" />
In 1988, he joined investment bank [[Goldman Sachs]] in New York.<ref name=":0" /> From 1988 to 1990, he was [[executive director]] of Goldman Sachs in [[New York City|New York]], then [[London]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=101004&privcapId=3486376|title=Walter Butler: Executive Profile & Biography|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bloomberg.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> He has stated that his experience with the firm was where much of his business knowledge was formed.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/economie/article/2008/02/21/walter-butler-achat-vente-occasions_1014113_3234.html|title=Walter Butler Achat, vente, occasions...|work=Le Monde.fr|access-date=2018-09-12|language=fr-FR}}</ref>
In 1991, he founded [[Butler Capital Partners]], an investment fund and venture capital business.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
Through Butler Capital Partners, Butler is known for his involvement with companies including Flo, Sernam, Ipsos, BDDP, PSG and Virgin.<ref name=":4" /> Butler is also known for his role in the privatization of ferry company National Corsican-Mediterranean Co., [[Maritima Ferries|SNCM]], in 2006.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.lesechos.fr/03/05/2015/lesechos.fr/02145239963_walter-butler-tente-de-relancer-isodev.htm|title=Walter Butler tente de relancer Isodev|work=lesechos.fr|access-date=2018-09-12|language=fr-FR}}</ref>
In 2008, Butler became a stakeholder in [[Virgin Megastores]] when Butler Capital Partners purchased a majority stake in [[Virgin Group]] from [[Lagardère Group|Lagardère]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/economie/article/2013/01/10/virgin-nouvel-echec-de-walter-butler_1814802_3234.html|title=Virgin, nouvel échec de Walter Butler|work=Le Monde.fr|access-date=2018-09-12|language=fr-FR}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bfmbusiness.bfmtv.com/emploi/est-butler-capital-partners-proprietaire-virgin-417348.html|title=Qui est Butler Capital Partners, le propriétaire de Virgin ?|last=BUSINESS|first=BFM|work=BFM BUSINESS|access-date=2018-09-12|language=fr-FR}}</ref>
In 2015, Butler led the acquisition of Isodev, an [[Small and medium-sized enterprises|SME]] loan platform that had been liquidated earlier that year.<ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.agefi.fr/financements-marches/actualites/quotidien/20150505/walter-butler-veut-capitaliser-marque-prets-139552|title=Walter Butler veut capitaliser sur la marque de prêts participatifs Isodev - Actualités Financements & Marchés|date=2015-05-05|work=L'AGEFI|access-date=2018-09-12|language=fr}}</ref>
In 2018, Butler became the largest shareholder of Noerden, a Shanghai-based startup that manufactures smart watches and other devices.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.fr/luxe/les-start-ups-qui-celebrent-la-culture-et-lart-de-vivre/?cn-reloaded=1|title=Les Start-Up Qui Célèbrent La Culture Et L'Art De Vivre {{!}} Forbes France|date=2018-02-14|work=Forbes France|access-date=2018-09-12|language=fr-FR}}</ref>
